The contribution of the project on the issuance of green bonds was corroborated by a Vinte speaker at FSMX19 and by a Banobras representative in the Mission to London. Regarding FIRA’s issuance, the project also provided exposure to the issuance process at FSMX19 and supported the underwriter though the training sessions to institutional investors.   
On June 5th, 2019 Vinte successfully placed long term sustainable debt (green and high social impact) for a total of $700 million MX pesos (USD 35 million) at the Bolsa Mexicana de Valores, which consisted of the issuance of two sustainable bonds with A+ credit rating and a sustainable favourable second opinion by Sustainalytics and sustainable rating of XB1 (highest sustainable rating) by HR Ratings. Likewise, Banobras consulted Sustainalytics to do the pre-issuance second opinion and their report highlighted that Banobras had identified projects, financed between March 31st, 2014, and March 31st, 2019, which were eligible for funding by the 2019 issuances. As a result, on August 31st, 2019 Banobras issued two new sustainable bonds for a total of $7,000 million MX pesos (USD 350 million). Finally, on November 21st, 2019 FIRA issued a certified bond for a total of $2,500 million MX pesos (USD 125 million). 
Q2 2020
Four additional sustainable bonds were issued in Mexico at the beginning of 2020: one by agricultural development bank FIRA; one by international development bank NadBank; one by Coca-Cola FEMSA ; and one by Rotoplas. The IP has confirmed that the project did not contribute to the issuance of these sustainable bonds except for the one of Rotoplas. For the latter, the investor announced their issuance at the FSMX19, to which a large portion of the Mexican investor community attended. The project also promoted the investor by showcasing the issuance of their first sustainable issuance through one of the case studies produced in the third quarter of 2019. The bond was issued on February 9th, 2020 for a total of $1,600 million MX pesos (USD 80 million).
Result_Title: Green bonds and green REIts issued
Description:
The number of green / sustainable / social bonds issued in Mexico increases. The target is 
to double the amount of bonds issued in 2018 (5 bonds) and issuing at least USD 1.5 billion.

Project: Mobilization of private investment to implement energy efficiency measures in the industrial sector in Colombia
Description_new:
Q3 2020
At the end of May 2020, the project started the implementation of a virtual course on 'Climate Change Corporate Carbon Footprint measurements and reports'.  The course finished in August 2020. The course lasted a total of 40 hours, and was attended by 70 people (27 were female) from industrial companies. 
Q1 2021
Considering the request of some companies, a second edition was carried out with a total of 41 registered participants. Information about gender was not provided.
Result_Title: Workshops on carbon accounting and GHG inventories
Description: Capacity building in carbon accounting and GHG inventories. These workshops will aim to upskill key staff in industries of interest in the preparation of corporate GHG emission inventories.

Project: Mobilization of private investment to implement energy efficiency measures in the industrial sector in Colombia
Description_new:
Q4 2019
Two webinars on energy efficiency best practice and energy efficiency opportunities for steam and heating systems were delivered in the last quarter of 2019. The webinars took place on November 20th and December 6th, 2019. A total of 92 participants attended the trainings, out of which 20 were female. Attendees belonged to industry companies, service and technology providers, and academic institutions.
Q1 2020
A two-days in person training on key lessons from energy efficiency projects was delivered in Bogota between 28 and 29 January 2020. The workshop was addressed to energy consultants from the implementing entities. 20 consultants from CAEM and CCEE attended: 17 males and 3 females. Prior to the training, a survey was administered to the implementing entities about their energy efficiency projects, and results from that survey were gathered and presented during this training session, as well as excel tools and other support documents.
Q4 2020
A total of 16 virtual workshops were developed across four regions included in the project: Antioquia, Atlantic Coast, Valle del Cauca and Bogotá. Considering all the editions carried out, there were a total of 133 participants from industry companies. 
Additionally, the project conducted five workshops on GHG inventories with industry companies across five cities: Bogotá, Cartagena, Barranquilla, Cali and Medellín. A total of 53 people (25 men and 28 women) attended the trainings, which were focused on the fundamentals of calculating the carbon footprint and GHG inventories of projects.
Result_Title: Workshops with industrial companies and auditors/consultants
Description: Capacity building for industrial companies and auditors/consultants through both in-person and online workshops. These workshops will include topics such as the efficient use of energy, formulation of energy efficiency projects and actions to improve the use of energy in thermal systems.

Project: Mobilization of private investment to implement energy efficiency measures in the industrial sector in Colombia
Description_new:
Q4 2019
A governance committee with key experts from every organisation was created in the last quarter of 2019, and the rules of operation of the committee agreed upon. Since its creation, weekly and ad-hoc meetings have taken place among key experts, where they have shared best practices and lessons learned across projects. 
Q4 2020
Up to the end of 2020, a total of 15 monthly meetings have taken place. 
Q1 2021
Up to Q1 2021, a total of 18 monthly meetings have taken place.
Result_Title: Governance committee with experts from every organization to transfer best practices
Description: Creation of a governance committee with experts from every organization. They will meet monthly to guarantee alignment and transfer of best practices across members.

Project: Mobilization of private investment to implement energy efficiency measures in the industrial sector in Colombia
Description_new:
Q3 2020
By the end of September 2020, 74 Energy Efficiency projects had been identified and profiled. Out of these, 70 of them had been presented to potential investors. Those projects with more acute financial needs were prioritized to obtain funding from local banks.
Q4 2020
By the end of December 2020, 92 Energy Efficiency projects had been identified and profiled. Out of these, 70 of them had been presented to potential investors, and 16 were already under implementation with companies’ own industrial resources. Moreover, 9 of them had been assessed by Bancoldex and the financial evaluation results were presented to the companies.
Q1 2021
By the end of March 2021, 98 Energy Efficiency projects had been identified and profiled by Colombia Productiva. This number surpassed the initial target of 90 profiled projects. Out of these, 30 were selected to be financially evaluated by Bancoldex. This financial evaluation mainly consisted in the analysis of the economic lifetime of the project, its income and growth projection, identification of investment and operational costs, definition of its financing structure, and risk and sensitivity analysis, among others. Three of these projects also received technical assistance to support them in the application to access tax benefits for investments in energy efficiency and non-conventional energy sources, which are managed by UPME and ANLA, and allow companies to acquire equipment without paying VAT or tariffs, as well as discounting their investment from the income tax. For each of the 30 selected projects, the project supported the elaboration of a complete business case which characterized the project with key information relevant to financial stakeholders: company financial statements, economic sector, revenue, level of indebtedness, financing needs, VPN; TIR, guarantees offered etc. Finally, Bancoldex presented the portfolio of the 30 bankable projects to key financial stakeholders, aiming to trigger the offer of credit to the specific companies/projects.
Result_Title: Identification and profiling of energy efficiency projects
Indicator: Output 2.3. 'Project application/ tools developed to access funds'
Description: Identification and profiling of EE projects: identification of energy efficiency, energy assessment with a focus on thermal energy, technical and economic feasibility.

Project: Mobilization of private investment to implement energy efficiency measures in the industrial sector in Colombia
Description_new:
Q3 2020
Out of the 70 projects which were presented to potential investors, 13 of them were agreed to be implemented by industrial companies. No more information is provided regarding the investment mobilized by these projects. 
Q4 2020
The number of projects agreed to be implemented by industrial companies increased up to 16. All of them are currently under implementation to different degrees. No more information is provided regarding the investment mobilized by these projects.
Q1 2021
By the end of March 2021, 36 energy efficiency projects were under implementation (out of an initial goal of 20 projects). 
Out of those 36 projects, 32 energy efficiency projects were financed with resources of the own industrial companies reaching a total amount of COP $10,656,141,514 (approximately USD $2.84 million). 
Furthermore, a total amount of COP $4,206,791,434 (approximately USD $1.12 million) were financed by local banks for two energy efficiency projects.
Finally, two additional projects were financed by technology providers investing more than COP $300,000,000 (approximately USD $80,000).
Result_Title: Finance investors show interest into energy efficiency projects
Description: Local banks and/or companies finance EE projects.

Project: Mobilization of private investment to implement energy efficiency measures in the industrial sector in Colombia
Description_new:
By the end of March 2021, 36 energy efficiency projects were under implementation (out of an initial goal of 20 projects). Out of those, 32 were financed by their industrial companies’ own resources, two by local banks, and two by technology providers. Nevertheless, no information was provided on the amounts of the investments already disbursed.  
For those projects who estimated savings and emissions reductions, it was calculated that energy savings will amount for up to 25,891 MWh/year, with economic savings at COP $3,653,617,932/year (USD $967,623 approximately) and GHG reductions at 7467.67tCO2e/year.
Result_Title: Energy efficiency projects are implemented
Description: Growth in the number of EE projects being implemented.

Project: Mobilization of private investment to implement energy efficiency measures in the industrial sector in Colombia
Description_new:
Q1 2020
The knowledge shared through the training sessions and compiled in the report on lessons learned on the design and implementation of industrial Energy Efficiency projects have been adopted by a wide range of industrial companies, and manifested in the following actions:
1) Out of the 52 participant companies (for a total of 56 industrial facilities), all of them have developed their own energy prediagnostics, which mainly serves to identify the core of energy consumption within the company. 
2) 37 facilities have also conducted energy characterizations, which include an energy efficiency plan and the identification of potential energy measures. 
3) 29 facilities have conducted expert walk-through energy assessments focused on steam and heating systems. 
4) 4 facilities have developed complete energy assessments with focus on thermal energy use (steam and other).
Q3 2020.
During the third quarter of 2020, more companies have advanced in the implementation of Energy Efficiency measures. In particular: 
1) 7 additional facilities have conducted energy characterizations, for a total of 44.
2) 5 additional expert walk-through energy assessments focused on steam and heating systems have taken place, for a total of 34. 
3) 2 additional facilities have developed complete energy assessments with focus on thermal energy use (steam and other), for a total of 6.
Q4 2020.
During the last quarter of 2020, more companies have advanced in the implementation of Energy Efficiency measures. In particular: 
1) 9 additional facilities have conducted energy characterizations, for a total of 53.
2) 6 additional expert walk-through energy assessments focused on steam and heating systems have taken place, for a total of 40. 
3) 9 additional facilities have developed complete energy assessments with focus on thermal energy use (steam and other), for a total of 15.
Q1 2021.
During the first quarter of 2021, more companies advanced in the implementation of Energy Efficiency measures. In particular: 
1) 3 additional facilities conducted energy characterizations, for a total of 56.
2) 2 additional expert walk-through energy assessments focused on steam and heating systems have taken place, for a total of 42. 
3) 10 additional facilities have developed complete energy assessments with focus on thermal energy use (steam and other), for a total of 25.
Result_Title: Companies develop energy efficiency plans
Indicator: Int. Out 1. 'Enhanced action because of training'
Description: Companies develop EE plans and implement best practices. This will include pre-energy diagnosis and  energy characterization.

Project: Catalysing local implementation of climate action: unleashing the potential of non-state actors.
Description_new:
Q4 2020
Significant advances were made on the identification and development of a portfolio of sustainable transport projects in the four participating cities. The list of selected projects is the following: 
Medellin
- Metro de la 80: 13-kilometre-long light rail project with 17 stations. 
- Cycling infrastructure densification project: 40 kilometres of cycling lanes laid-out throughout the city.
Cali
- Tren de Cercanías: 70-kilometre regional train connecting the municipality of Cali with neighbouring municipalities of Palmira, Yumbo and Jamundí.
- Sustainable mobility project: construction of 110 kilometres of cycling lanes and 161 new bicycle parking modules. 
Pereira
- Mega Cable: new cable car project for the city of Pereira. Currently in structuring phase. 
- Electric buses: replacement of 40 articulated buses and 116 small buses, from combustion to electric technologies. 
Monteria
- Businú phase 2: river transportation system along the Sinú river. 
- Bicired: construction of 80 kilometres of cycling lanes.
In addition to the identification of the sustainable mobility projects in each city, the project already conducted a technical evaluation for each one of them. The technical evaluations included calculations of the projects’ potential for GHG emissions reductions, co-benefits expected, potential gender impact, estimation of implementation costs, economic appraisal, risk assessments, and identification of key barriers. 
Q1 2021
During the first quarter of 2021, WWF produced final project reports highlighting the results for each of the selected projects, as well as the package containing the spreadsheets used for calculations in the technical evaluations. Moreover, in each of the participating cities, the project delivered a dissemination workshops where they presented the evaluation methodology and results for two of the sustainable transport projects.
Result_Title: Set of potential projects to be implemented to decarbonize the transport sector
Indicator: Output 2.3. 'Project application/ tools developed to access funds'
Description: Identify a set of potential projects which could be implemented in Medellin, Cali, Pereira and Monteria to decarbonize the transport sector. Utilise robust and coherent information in order to present the portfolio to climate finance funds: calculate the potential reduction of GHG emissions that would be generated if the projects are implemented, estimate costs of projects’ implementation, estimate projects’ co-benefits, and identify barriers.

Project: Catalysing local implementation of climate action: unleashing the potential of non-state actors.
Description_new:
Q2 2020
The project, in collaboration with MADS and IDEAM, started developing a GHG emission inventories guide which contains the methodology for updating the cities' inventories of GHG emissions and MRV design for transport projects. Advances were mainly made in the stationary energy, transport, and wasting management sectors.
The importance of the guide comes from the fact that it will allow Colombian cities update their emission inventories easily, and it will facilitate inventories comparisons across cities. Up to date, emission inventories are the first step in order to select which mitigation actions will be prioritised by cities for their contributions to the NDCs.
Q4 2020
In the second half of 2020, the project developed the methodologies for the AFOLU and the IPPU (Industrial Processes and Product Use) sectors. As a result of the work developed, GHG inventories were updated for Medellín, Montería, Cali and Pereira with the information collected by technical personnel of WWF throughout the course of this project. 
Q1 2021
The final version of the guide and tool developed throughout the implementation of the project were launched at a virtual event in March 2021 to a total of 134 attendees. The event transmission can be reproduced in the following link: http://youtu.be/V--sZiJrkTA
Result_Title: GHG emission inventories guide
Description: Build a guide, with the collaboration of MADS and IDEAM, which contains the methodology for updating the cities' inventories of GHG emissions and MRV design for transport projects.  The focus of the guide will be the calculation of GHG emissions reduction in transport projects and the design of the MRV system of transport projects, as well as related registration in the RENARE. However, it will also contain guidance on the methodology for calculations of emission inventories in other sectors, to help and guide the Colombian cities of interest in the update of their whole inventory for the city.

Project: Catalysing local implementation of climate action: unleashing the potential of non-state actors.
Description_new:
Q4 2020
By the end of 2020, GHG inventories had been completely updated for Medellín, Montería, Cali and Pereira with the information collected by technical personnel of WWF and the collaboration of government personnel in each city. 
Moreover, MRV systems for the eight selected transport projects were already designed and socialized among key stakeholders, and technical trainings were conducted in all the cities. The pending activity was the registration of the projects in RENARE, aimed to quantify the projects’ contributions to the NDCs. 
Q1 2021. 
Results of the updated GHG inventory were presented to the relevant entities in a series of socialisation events during the first quarter of 2021. 
Furthermore, with respect to the development of MRV systems for transport projects, all four cities sent an official communication to MADS agreeing to report at least one of their transport projects into RENARE for them to be accounted into the country’s NDC.
Result_Title: Mayoralties implement the updated GHG inventories guide
Description: The mayoralties of the cities of Cali, Pereira, Monteria, and Medellin implement the new GHG emission inventories guide:  they use it for the update of their cities' inventories and the design and implementation of MRV systems in the transport sector

Project: City of Johannesburg Electric Vehicle Readiness Support
Description_new: The meeting had the participation of representatives from City of Johannesburg, City Power and SEA. Lebo Molefe and Thabo Mahlatsi (Directors in the Environment & Infrastructure Services Department) formally adopted the project into their Department. The steering committee, composed by representatives of City of Johannesburg, City Power and SEA, was agreed on and participants were excited to see the project get underway.
Result_Title: City of Johannesburg Electric Vehicle Readiness Steering Committee established
Description: Committed participation from senior officials in the departments of climate change, energy (City Power), finance, transport and planning. The steering committee will provide guidance on alignment with city goals, on vertical alignment, and champion acceleration of EV uptake in the city.

Project: Scaling up Colombia Green Growth Policy implementation and investments via capacity building of state and non-state actors
Description_new:
Q4 2019
Project 1: Design and structuring of a 3x9.9MWac solar photovoltaic (PV) cluster in Tolima. On December 20th of 2019, GGGI technical and transaction advisory support led to the signing of a Letter of Intent between the RE developer (RAYO), and an equity investor (GRODCO) for the construction of the 3x9.9MWac PV cluster with an estimated investment cost of USD 28.2 million. The interconnection application and termsheet with landowner have been approved and signed by the parties. The project's power marketing is expected to be completed by Q4 2020, with a construction period of 9-12 months, leading to a commercial operation date (COD) in Q4 2021. 
Q3 2020
Project 1: GGGI reports that on July 20th, 2020 the project has successfully signed a Letter of Intent with RAYO (developer) and GRODCO (investor) for the development and construction of the 4x12MWp solar PV cluster with an estimated investment cost of USD 40 million, rather than the initially signed of 28.2m.
Project 4: A USD 32 million Letter of Intent was signed on September 7th, 2020 between ICP, GGGI and ISC.
Q4 2020
Project 3: On December 3th, 2020 GGGI signed a USD 6.1 million Letter of Intent with GICON and Neco Power for the development of the project. The plant’s detailed engineering design is expected to be completed in April 2021, followed by procurement and delivery of other project components during a period of five months. GICON will lead the engineering and construction of the plant over a period of 7-8 months, leading to an approximate commercial operation date of Q1 2022.
Result_Title: Mobilization of investments in NCRE projects and bio-economy businesses
Description: Mobilize investments in non-conventional renewable energy projects and bio-economy businesses. A written commitment from investors before the end of the projects.

Project: Catalysing local implementation of climate action: unleashing the potential of non-state actors.
Description_new:
Given the health crisis triggered by the COVID-19 pandemic, the capacity building component of this project had to be redesigned completely. 
Q2 2020
During the second quarter of 2020 (between April and June), the project conducted four independent online workshops about updating GHG emission inventories, one with each participant city (Cali, Medellin, Monteria, and Pereira). 
Each workshop had an approximate duration of half a day, and the topic of discussion was the methodology for updating the emissions reduction inventory of the city, and potential information sources for that update. 
In total, 39 key stakeholders were trained, out of which 22 were female: 18 in Cali (13 female), 7 in Monteria (3 female), 7 in Medellin (5 female), and 7 in Pereira (1 female). Attendees belonged to the following institutions: the Administrative Department of Environment Management in Cali, the Secretary of Mobility in Cali, the Secretary of Planning in Cali, the Ministry of Environment, the Secretary of Planning and 'Ciudad Verde' in Monteria, the Secretary of Mobility in Medellín, the Secretary of Environment in Medellín, and the Secretary of Environment and Rural Development in Pereira.
Q4 2020
During the second half of 2020, the project continued building the capacity of key individuals from local governments of the four participating cities. On average, 84 (38 female) individuals were trained on the following topics: i) how to use the tools (spreadsheets) created by the project for the update of the national GHG inventory (INGEI) at the city level, ii) the GHG inventory structure for the AFOLU sector and particularities of its data requirements, iii) MRV design and reporting in general, and iv) MRV design and reporting for specific projects such as cycling infrastructure or cable cars. 
Attendees belonged to the following institutions: IDEAM, the Administrative Department of Environment Management in Cali, the Secretary of Planning in Monteria, the Secretary of Mobility in Medellín, and the Secretary of Environment and Rural Development in Pereira.
Q1 2021
During the first quarter of 2021, the project trained a total of 75 key stakeholders (35 were female) across four trainings events on how to report projects in the RENARE platform (average duration 0.25 days). These trainings were delivered in partnership with MADS, following the official agreement of all cities to register at least one of the transport projects for which an MRV was designed into RENARE. 
During this quarter, the project also conducted a three-days training (2.5 hours sessions per day) on how to use the guide and tool to elaborate GHG inventories in Colombian cities. The training included all the specifics about how to use the tool while using the guide to inform the official guide to inform the process. Additionally, the training was designed to explain the process and assumptions for all subsectors in the stationary energy, transport, waste management, IPPU and AFOLU sectors. A total of 161 stakeholders participated in the workshop (91 were female).
Attendees belong to the following institutions: the Secretary of Mobility in Bogota, the Colombian Federation of Municipalities (FCM), MADS, the governorships of Caldas and Cundinamarca, academia, and the private sector, among others.
Result_Title: Six capacity building workshops for local government civil servants
Description: Carry out at least six capacity building workshops for local government civil servants on calculation of GHG emissions inventories (1 workshop for civil servants from 4 cities), MRV system design and registration in RENARE (4 workshops, 1 per city) and environmental and financial structuring of urban sustainable transport projects (1 workshop for civil servants from 4 cities)

Project: Scaling up Colombia Green Growth Policy implementation and investments via capacity building of state and non-state actors
Description_new:
Q1 2020
During the first quarter of 2020, the project defined and developed a reference framework which constituted the basis on which to conduct a gap analysis at the subnational level for each indicator of interest. The project has also conducted the normalization of selected indicators using both national and international methodologies, as well as the analysis of green growth indicators reported at the subnational level. Technical discussions on the reference framework and indicator standardisation were held with the DNP. 
Q2 2020
A first draft version of the IGG Index was finalised and presented to DNP for review. A second version is expected for August 2020, after which the IGGIndex will enter a validation process with subnational stakeholders, private sector, and academy. Publication and launch of the GGGIndex is expected for Q1 of 2021. 
Q3 2020
During the third quarter of 2020, GGGI finalized the technical support to DNP for designing the Green Growth Index (GGGI). A final version of the index was presented, together with indications on interpretation analysis and recommendations for further development and tailoring for sectorial and regional contexts. 
The IGGIndex is expected to help the national government, the private sector, and academia to track the implementation of the green growth policy, identify gaps across regions, identify investment opportunities, and mobilize resources.
Result_Title: Inclusive Green Growth Index
Description: An Inclusive Green Growth Index (IGG Index) will be jointly developed with DNP and will enable the monitoring, reporting, and verification of GGP implementation at the sub-national level.

Project: Mexico inward skillshare: Green Finance
Description_new: The head of the International Affairs Office from Banobras attended events in parallel with municipality representatives. These included meetings with HSBC (to discuss including climate risk in project risk assessments), Carbon Trust (which the representative felt was the least useful part of training given they'd seen the presentation before), Green Investment Group (which covered lessons from opening a Green Investment Bank in Mongolia and how these apply to Mexico)  and the Green Finance Initiative (who shared experience of designing the Green Finance Strategy), attending the Public Sector Green Finance Summit and attending training on sustainable finance run by the University of Oxford
Result_Title: Attendance of Banobras to the GFPS summit in the UK
Description: Attendance by the Head of the International Affairs Office from Banobras to the Green Finance Public Sector Summit Event and a series of meetings with UK stakeholders, alongside representatives from 6 municipalities. The main topic of discussion was the development of the UK's Green Finance Strategy.

Project: UK-China Green Finance Programme
Description_new:
On June 22nd, 2020, the project delivered a public webinar and a subsequent roundtable to present and discuss the key findings of the report 'Resilience: Lessons to Scale Responsible Investing'. The discussion was attended by around 20 key Chinese institutions, where the largest Chinese asset owners and managers (e.g. National Social Security Fund, Ping An, China Universal Asset Management, China Investment Corporation) provided insights around the report's key recommendations. The event had simultaneous translation, encouraging Chinese institutions to participate. The webinar was recorded, captioned in Chinese, and is now publicly available on the UK-China Green Finance Centre website to help communicate key messages from the analysis.
The goal of this event was to bring together UK and China senior asset owners and managers to discuss pragmatic ways to accelerate the deployment of ESG investment mandates and to discuss best practice lessons and recommendations. The discussion aimed to move beyond risk management and reporting, and focused on the real solutions and actions investors are taking to allocate capital for a sustainable economic recovery. 
The event lasted half a day, and the number of attendees is approximate (gender of attendees has not been provided). 
The webinar recording and bilingual report is available at: https://www.ukchinagreen.org/event/webinar-launch-resilience-lessons-to-scale-responsible-investing-report/ and
https://www.ukchinagreen.org/publication/new-report-shows-greater-cooperation-between-uk-and-chinese-investors-can-accelerate-sustainable-covid-19-recovery/
Result_Title: Workshop for Chinese long-term investors on green investment
Description: A workshop to build capacity among Chinese long-term investors on green investment.

Project: Sustaining the Growth of China’s Green Bond Market and Facilitating Inter-Country Green Capital Flows
Description_new:
Q2 2019
The project conducted a workshop on green building investment opportunities in Shanghai in April 2019. The workshop was jointly organized by CBI, Lujiazhui Financial City, Shanghai Banking Association, and Shanghai Green Building Association. 
A total of 30 participants attended the workshop, out of which 10 were female. Participants were representatives from leading financial institutions (Bank of Shanghai, Shanghai Pudong Development Bank, China Ag. bank), Shanghai Banking Association, Shanghai Green Building Association, real estate developers, law firms and real estate service agencies based in Shanghai. 
This workshop was conducted just once month after China released its new 'Green Industries Guidance Catalogue' to help promote green development through clarifying the definition of 'green industry' as well as harmonizing differing standards for sustainability. Indeed, in March 2019, Ministries came together to launch the catalogue, including the National Development and Reform Commission, the People’s Bank of China, and the Ministry of Ecology and Environment. These government bodies touched upon the key aspects of green industry from finance to buildings, energy, and new technologies. The workshop organized by CBI therefore aimed to capture the momentum of the policy push, and actively promote the development of green buildings and green real estate, as well as green finance standards and green technologies among the potential green building developers, dealers, and green bond issuers in the Yangtse river delta region. It helped to kick start an enthusiasm among the market stakeholders to use green finance/bond to support their green building portfolio.
Q4 2019
Another green bond market workshop was jointly conducted by CBI with Syntao Green Finance, Lianhe Equator, and ICMA as part of the China SIF week in Beijing in December 2019. The workshop targeted Chinese green bond issuers and potential issuers, green finance advisors, green bond verifiers, and potential investors. The event was attended by approximately 60 participants from the industry (25 female). The topic of the workshop was green bond market development and innovation. 
This green bond market workshop helped to further stimulate the market enthusiasm in green bond issuance and helped revitalize the conversation around green finance in China with innovative practices and latest updates from the market.
Q2 2020
Due to COVID-19 outbreak, and the impossibility to continue with on-site trainings, the project conducted an online webinar on the 28th of May 2020, together with CCX and a few Jiangshu-based green bond issuers/underwriters in China. No information about the number of attendees was provided.
Result_Title: Capacity building and market education workshops for five or six cities in China
Description: Hosting capacity building and market education workshops for five or six cities in China (such as Beijing, Shanghai, Huzhou, and Shenzhen, etc.)

Project: Promoting forest protection and peace-building through community-based ecotourism
Description_new:
Formal training of community ecotourism providers has taken place virtually in the three regions of interest to a different extent. In Serranía de las Quinchas, three capacity building modules were delivered.  First, an ‘ethnobotanical characterization’ training was delivered through a WhatsApp group created for this purpose, with a participation of 48 community members (24 female). In this training, the community learnt about the importance of ethnobotany and its relationship with tourism, the different uses of local plants and their potential contribution to the territory, and the wealth of biodiversity in the territory. The project also delivered a podcast on ‘touristic routes and the integration of the value chain’, with a participation of 26 people (16 female). In this training, the community learnt how to completely develop a comprehensive tourism proposal. Finally, an ‘introduction to community agreements’ was made to 27 people (20 female), where the community learnt about COVID-19, its relation to biodiversity loss, the challenges and opportunities for ecotourism products, and the importance of community agreements in this context. In Bocas del Atrato, the podcast on ‘touristic routes and the integration of the value chain’ was shared with the community. Moreover, an expert on biodiversity helped facilitate two other trainings: an introduction to community agreements with a participation of 14 people (11 female), and a training on ‘tourism and market niches’ 14 attendees (11 female). Through the latter, the community learnt about the characteristics of community tourism, the profile of nature tourists, and bird watching. Finally, in Serranía del Perijá, the project first delivered the ‘ethnobotanical characterization’ training to 20 attendees (6 female). The project also delivered the podcast on ‘touristic routes and the integration of the value chain’ to 18 community members (5 female). The ‘introduction to community agreements’ was attended by 25 people (7 female). 
For more detail on the training courses please enter to https://formacion.e3asesorias.com/
Result_Title: Formal training of community ecotourism providers
Description:
Formal training of community ecotourism providers. 
A total of three training modules will be delivered through virtual trainings. The three modules will include community agreement, tourism practices, and marketing.

Project: Building a sustainable and scalable low carbon future in Mexico<U+200B>
Description_new: On February 7th, 2020, CBI organized a workshop on Green Bonds together with the Consejo Consultivo de Finanzas Verdes (CCFV), addressed to Bolsa Mexicana de Valores (BMV)’s internal staff. The workshop had a duration of half a day and was delivered to a total of 23 people (9 female), mainly sales people at BMV.
Result_Title: Additional workshop to Bolsa Mexicana de Valores
Description: NA

Project: China Skill Share: Training to enhance understanding of domestic and global green finance development and Shenzhen's newly-issued Green Finance Regulation (CN-001a-R)
Description_new:
On 25th and 26th March 2021, Shenzhen held green finance training for financial institutes and regulators registered in the Shenzhen economic zone. This was a one and half day event supported by Shenzhen Local Financial and Supervisory Management Bureau and the People’s Bank of China Shenzhen Centre Branch. The training was to help their financial institutions to better understand the newly launched "Shenzhen Special Economic Zone Green Finance Regulations" and the necessary implementation measures. The aim of the event was to help enhance awareness and knowledge, and learn from international best practice. As such, our experts (Joss Blamire and Rachel Brisley) each developed and pre-recorded a 45-minute presentation on one of the key themes at the event (both presented on 25th March). 

Rachel presented on climate risk assessment and stress testing for the financial service sector in Shenzhen. She considered Shenzhen’s changing climate, impacts for financial institutions and other businesses, global trends and best practices on stress testing and climate risk assessment methodology. Joss presented on TCFD, a framework to help companies report on exposure to climate-related risks and opportunities. He provided a high level introduction to TCFD, best practice for disclosures to make in a report, and a roadmap to work towards producing a report. He explained what the TCFD recommendations are and why they are adopted worldwide. Both experts used relevant case studies to help illustrate their content.

The event was supported by Shenzhen Local Financial and Supervisory Management Bureau and People’s Bank of China Shenzhen Centre Branch. 97 financial institutions (with over 100 audience members) attended the training event, as well as Shenzhen financial regulators. We received feedback forms from 28 attendees (which have been attached/manually uploaded). This low number was likely due to the language challenge (the feedback forms were only in English). Other attendees may not have wanted to complete the forms.
Result_Title: Green finance development and regulatory training sessions (TCFD) with senior officials from Shenzhen government and financial institutions
Description: NA

Project: Climate Transition Pathways
Description_new: NBI conducted a series of workshops involving the project steering committee and advisory boards from Q3 and Q4 2020 with the aim of producing a multi-stakeholder engagement report. The report summaries stakeholders which NBI engaged with on the project in the business sector, with government, labour and civil society and outlines COP26 communication opportunities. These workshops consisted of three to six-hour hour long online workshops held via MS Teams. To date there have been 4 advisory meetings which took place on 11th September 2020, 9th October 2020, 19th November 2020, and 27th November 2020. These advisory board discussions were with members from industry, government, labour, and civil society from the following organisations: BCG, Congress of South African Trade Unions, The Council for Scientific and Industrial Research, Department of Environmental Affairs, Forestry and Fisheries, Just Share, Minerals Council, NBI, Navitas Holdings Proprietary Limited, TIPS, University of Cape Town and WFF. The purpose of these meetings was to discuss climate change in the South African context, provide an overview of the project, status update, content development approach and governance structure, share an overview of analysis and findings in the electricity sector, energy modelling approach, last mile decarbonization, green H2- the opportunity is real, emerging view on just transition for coal, recap of project timelines and engagement, and petrochemical decarbonization pathway and outlook for the rest of the year and 2021. The first advisory meeting was attended by 8 females and 12 males; second advisory meeting was attended by 8 females and 13 males; third advisory meeting was attended by 8 females and 12 males and fourth advisory meeting was attended by 9 females and 15 males.NBI held a total of 4 steering committee meetings which took place on 14th September 2020, 02nd October 2020, 11 November 2020 and 30 Novermber 2020. The steering committee consisted of individuals from the following organisations: Anglo American, BCG, BUSA, Engen, Eskom, Exxaro, FirstRand, JSE, Knowledge Pele, NBI, Sasol, The Banking Association of South Africa, Transnet, Glencore FerroAlloys, Harmony Gold, Minerals Council, NBI, Sibanye StillWater. The following agenda topics were covered in these meetings: :steering committee introductions, recap – project context and status update, content development approach, overview of governance structure, : presentation the overview of findings and analysis on the electricity sector, group discussion on the RE archetype as point for net-zero pathway development and green H2, discussion on Just Transition challenges in mining and recap of project timelines and engagement plan, key objectives and status update, overview of CEO meeting content, key findings on power sector modelling , the Just Transition as a key to enable to transformation, role of gas. The first meeting was attended by 11 males and 10 females, the second meeting was attended by 9 females and 12 males, the third meeting was attended by 18 females and 20 males, and the fourth meeting was 15 females and 9 males.
Result_Title: Technical Advisory Meetings with Government, CSO, and Labour Union stakeholders.
Description: A series of technical advisory meetings with civil society groups, labour unions, and government officials. The aim of the meetings is to achieve broad consensus on transition pathways in the following sectors (electricity, mining, petrochemicals) and influence government policy making.

Project: Supporting Mexico’s Green Finance Hub<U+200B>
Description_new: Between June 30th and July 4th, 2019, a mission to London to attend the Green Finance Summit organized by the Green Finance Initiative was undertaken. This event provided training on the latest in green financial policy trends, market developments and thought leadership. Most attendees were industry experts, policymakers, and some leading voices in green finance in the country.
Result_Title: Three day mission to London to meet the British institutional investors community
Description: A three-day mission to London to meet the British institutional investors community and authorities to exchange best practices in investment decision-making and regulation on green infrastructure.

Project: Malaysia outward skillshare: Developing a Climate Change Act and Climate change centre
Description_new:
Using insights from the workshops and other scoping work, two reports were produced: 
One on the Climate Change Act/climate legislation – this contained recommendations that had already been suggested before the skill-share, but not many inputs were incorporated during the visit itself. 
One on the Climate Change Centre – this did contain some recommendations that were somewhat relevant to the conversations which occurred during the skill-share.
Result_Title: Study recommending how Malaysia could implement its own climate change legislation and CCC
Description: Using insights from the workshops and other scoping work, the UK experts will produce a scoping study recommending how Malaysia could implement its own climate change legislation and national CCC.

Project: Malaysia outward skillshare: Developing a Climate Change Act and Climate change centre
Description_new:
Workshop on the UK Climate Change Act and Committee on Climate Change.
Overview of CCA and CCC provided by experts involved in skill share to Malaysian representatives, including Dr Nagulendran (MESTECC Deputy Secretary General) and Mr Jayasignham Raju (MESTECC climate change officer).
Result_Title: Workshop on the UK Climate Change Act and Committe on Climate Change
Description: Workshop with Malaysian stakeholders to enhance understanding of the UK's experience in establishing the UK Climate Change Act (2008) and the Committee on Climate Change through presentations by two UK experts.

Project: Malaysia outward skillshare: Developing a Climate Change Act and Climate change centre
Description_new: The skills and knowledge enhanced through the skill-share validated the need for a Climate Change Centre. Dr Nagu, Deputy Secretary General of the Ministry of Energy, Science, Technology, Environment and Climate Change (MESTECC) commented that the recommendation reports from the mission had become the basis to justify the decision to transition the Malaysian Green Technology Corporation (MGTC) into a CCC.  It is important to note here that the skill share did not lead to the decision to have an equivalent of CCC, which had already been decided, but it provided evidence in supporting this move. However, since the announcement of the transition there has been no evidence that MGTC has been able to function as a CCC as it had originally been intended.
Result_Title: Malaysian stakeholders buy-in to the recommendation set out in the scoping study
Indicator: Int. Out 2. 'Adoption of recommendation for policy/legislation'
Description: Malaysian stakeholders buy-in to the recommendations set out in the scoping study, and accept the need for a CCA and a CCC

Project: Strengthening the Legislative-Executive-Stakeholder dialogue on Mexico's climate change and energy goals
Description_new: The official presentation of the updated proposal for the LMACCDS in August 2020 was followed by a ruling process in Mexico City’s Congress and triggered several months of discussions, in which POLEA was able to participate.
Result_Title: Adoption of the proposal to update Mexico City’s Law on Climate Change Adaptation, Mitigation and Sustainable Development
Indicator: Int. Out 2. 'Adoption of recommendation for policy/legislation'
Description: NA

Project: Strengthening the Legislative-Executive-Stakeholder dialogue on Mexico's climate change and energy goals
Description_new:
Q2 2020
During the second quarter of 2020, Polea signed a collaboration agreement with the Preservation of the Environment, Climate Change and Ecological and Animal Protection Commission (PECCEAPC) of Mexico City’s Congress, through which Polea committed to the delivery of a proposal for the update of Mexico City’s Law on Climate Change Adaptation, Mitigation and Sustainable Development (LMACCDS).
To inform the process, Polea developed a participative approach, conducting consultations with a wide range of stakeholders. In particular, the project deployed an online questionnaire to collect the views of 96 stakeholders on the matter. Moreover, 26 in-depth interviews were conducted with experts and key informants from different sectors. The project also held consultation meetings with high level officers from SEDEMA and five legislators from different political parties. The participative process also included the delivery of two webinars to almost 150 participants, which included interested local legislators, government representatives, and thematic specialists. All the collected evidence was analysed and put together on an executive study which summarised key findings of this participative process. 
Q3 2020
The extraordinary session of the PECCEAPC of Mexico City’s Congress took place on Monday August 3rd, 2020, and POLEA officially presented the updated proposal for the Law on Mitigation and Adaptation to Climate Change and Sustainable Development for Mexico City.
Result_Title: Document with legal proposals and analysis to update Mexico City’s Law on Climate Change Adaptation, Mitigation and Sustainable Development (LMACCDS)
Description: NA

Project: Strengthening the Legislative-Executive-Stakeholder dialogue on Mexico's climate change and energy goals
Description_new: The updated LMACCDS was approved by the Congress on May 25th, and it came into force on June 10th, 2021. The new legislation is designed to be Paris Agreement compliant, and it includes a legally binding commitment to reach Net Zero by 2050. The country’s capital, home to over 9 million people (and 21 million in the broader metropolitan area), becomes the first subnational entity in the country to commit to carbon neutrality in Mexico, highlighting the significant opportunity to accelerate climate action at the sub national level.
Result_Title: Update of Mexico City’s Law on Climate Change Adaptation, Mitigation and Sustainable Development
Description: NA

Project: Promoting green recovery by championing the power of disclosure, transparency and UK-China collaboration
Description_new:
CDP has responded to policy consultations and arranged three meetings in Q1 with staff of CSRC, MEE and SEE:
1.	CDP submitted a response to the public consultation on the Guidelines for Investor Relations Management of Listed Companies of China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) on March 5th, 2021, and organised a discussion with the Shanghai Stock Exchange (SSE) to collect further suggestions.
2.	CDP met an analyst of the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) on 18 March 2021 to learn updated status of upcoming disclosure regulations. The analyst is in charge of drafting disclosure regulations which is expected to be released in 2021/2022. Following the meeting, CDP provided its Climate Change indicators and Prototype climate-related financial disclosure standard to support CSRC’s research.
3.	CDP had a catch up meeting with the Chinese Academy of Environmental Planning (CAPE), an Institute of the Ministry of Ecology and Environment (MEE) on 23 March  2021. Following this meeting, CDP provided its Climate Change indicators to support CAPE’s research on law-based environmental information disclosure. CAPE will be influential in recommending/advising the types of indicators that will be adopted by CSRC new regulatory framework.
Result_Title: Quarterly meetings of national policy makers from MEE and CSRC
Description: Timely (quarterly) updates with policy makers from the MEE and the CSRC to exchange research learnings, trends in environment disclosure, and insights.

Project: Operationalising Energy Performance Certificates in South Africa
Description_new: The final report (titled NBEPR User needs, functionality and technical outline, data management and governance policies report) firstly identifies the key user needs that the NBEPR must serve. This is done by both extracting the key relative findings from the previous report (Report of investigation into international EPC best practice to address opportunities and barriers for the local EPC mechanism) and by building on these through interviews with local EPC mechanism actors and additional desktop research. The report then identifies they key functional and non-functional specifications to which the NBEPR must be built in order to meet these user needs. While these are dealt with at a high level in the main body of the report, the appendix provides detailed specifications. These specifications will be translated into technical requirements in the following report (Report of National Building Energy Performance Register (NBEPR) functional and technical specification, and reporting protocols). While this report does not make direct policy recommendations, it provides a basis for ensuring that existing EPC policy is effectively served through the specifications of the NBEPR.
Result_Title: Report of National Building Energy Performance Register (NBEPR)
Description: Two reports on the National Building Energy Performance Register (NBEPR). The first report will ensure that the NBEPR meets all user and technical requirements, and complies with local data regulations, and in line with international best practice. The consortium will work with a data scientist (funded by SANEDI) to support this process. The second report will use prior outputs to finalise the functionality that the NBEPR must have to maximise its impact. It will also support alignment of NBEPR functionality alignment with reporting requirements as stated in the draft EPC regulation, and in line with DEFF’s national emissions reporting requirements for buildings.

Result_Title: GIRO Zero Network established among key stakeholders that could potentially benefit the sector as a whole by easing measurement, reporting, and verification (MRV) of emissions generated within the sector, as well as data sharing among stakeholders

Project: Steering the Colombian Road Freight Sector Towards a Zero Emissions Strategy GIRO-ZERO
Description_new:
The Industry Review report is divided into different sections in which each refers to best practices in the UK and Latam, state of the art in Colombia, and identifies gaps and to-dos for Colombia in the Road Freight Transport sector
The report identifies sustainable Road Freight Transport KPIs, best practices applied in the industry (e.g. vehicle and alternative fuel technologies, industrial organisation, digitalisation of logistics networks and optimisation, green road infrastructure), and determines the feasibility of their adoption in different segments of the industry.
Also, it identifies risks, barriers, and the latest trends related to the adoption of green practices within the Colombian Road Freight Transport sector and next steps.
The report is written in English (102 pages) along with a summarized report in Spanish. 
This Industry review report was presented to beneficiary institutions such as the Ministry of Transport on 21 June 2021, and COLFECAR on 22 June 2021.
Result_Title: Industry Review Report on the current state of green technologies and practices in the trucking industry in Colombia
Description:
RFT Industry Review Report on: 
1) Identification sustainable Road Freight Transport KPIs, best practices applied in industry (e.g. vehicle and alternative fuel technologies, digitalisation
of logistics networks, green road infrastructure), and determine the feasibility of their adoption in different segments of the industry.
2)  Identification of drivers, barriers and latest trends related to the adoption of green practices within the Colombian Road Freight Transport sector.
The results of this report will also be an input for an evaluation toolbox and strategic business plan.

Project: Supporting livelihoods through Ecotourism Routes for Forest and Peace.
Description_new:
[PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT 2021-Q2]:  
From April 21, 2021 to May 3, 2021, Johani Gaviria, a professional tourism guide and ally of Think Tourism, visited the Serranía del Perijá and the Serranía de las Quinchas to do a dry run of the tourism routes designed during UK PACT I. The purpose was to analyse the routes' viability and understand the communities' preparedness and engagement across the tourism supply chain (food, homestays, guidance, transport, etc). 
In Quinchas, with the support of Boyapaz, the routes were operated by different actors in each of the subregions (Altazor, Nazareth, Betania, Camilo, Curubita, Quinchas), who accompanied and guided Johani, provided food and accommodations for his stay. The dry-run was very useful and truly made the community understand the value of their region, biodiversity, and gastronomic knowledge. Tourism resources include natural and landscape resources such as waterfalls, viewpoints, caves, and endemic flora and fauna. It also includes culinary tourism resources, such as "nacuma" or "fruta del pan," a local plant used to produce sweets and fermented beverages. Similarly, there's an agritourism experience in a cocoa farm. Johani empowered them to truly realize that those are the true important attractive selling points of the region. Among the strengths, Johani identified their cultural gastronomy as very unique, using various edible plants of the jungle (although this is not seen in any restaurant in Otanche) to do local, special preparations. 
In Perijá, there are already two tourism operators established which delivered the tourism routes. The first visit was to the mountains near the township Estados Unidos, and the second one to La Victoria, where there are coffee farms and the entry to the mountains. Similar to Perijá, there are also various natural tourism resources such as waterfalls, viewpoints, pristine Andean forests, and rich biodiversity with great potential for bird watching (e.g. Quetzales and endemic Gorrión del Perijá). Among the strengths identified, Johani confirmed that people are highly committed to the project and to working together as a whole in order to propel tourism in the area and make it a vital economic activity for them. 
For both destinations, the major weakness is the lodging offerings. Both destinations need homestay improvements to ensure visitors have minimum standards such as: bathroom with running water, beds, electricity access, and privacy. Additional recommendations for both destinations include: defining a governance strategy, define a plan for emergency response, training on hygiene and biosecurity protocols (for all lodging, gastronomy, and guidance), training in ophidian accidents, creating an inventory of transport offerings in the areas, and develop marketing and informative material. Both regions also have cultural tourism resources that could be explored (such as traditional dances, music, and crafts).
Result_Title: Detailed tourist plans/packages in Quinchas and Perijá
Description:
Two (2) multi-day tour plans/package, one for Quinchas and one Perijá, that will include: : (i) A description of the regions, (ii) the expected goals of the touristic routes, inviting tourists to be part of the expected vision of change, (iii) a brief description of the eco-tourist attractions, (iv) the description of the tours with the detailed itineraries, (iv) the description of the services involved, (v) the investment (cost) of the different itineraries, (vi) references to relevant tools/information including biodiversity booklets and web pages. 
Each tourist plan/packages will be tested with 3 pilot tours with actual tourists that are able to provide feedback and recommendations. Recommendations will be analysed with the tourists and communities to produce enhanced tourist plans/packages. The first pilot tour will be developed with Colombians that are more connected to the communities or willing to support. The second will have one international tourists, if possible, and involve Think Galapagos to support the refinement process. The third pilot could involve an influencer, national or international tourists, and Think Galapagos and Acorn experts. The tours will involve small groups of maximum 6 people. All the arrangements will be developed with the communities, testing their skills. Each visit is a multi-day tour, involving various activities.

In addition there will be a dry run test of the routes designed last year by professional tourism guide and operator. A report with recommendations on the tourist routes will be provided in 2021-Q2.

Project: Empowering territories’ for low carbon transformation
Description_new:
On May 26-27, 2021, two online workshops on pathways frameworks and long-term vision settings were completed from 9:00 am to 12 pm. The keynote speakers included the Minister of Environment, the National Attorney General Officer for Environmental Affairs, and the Deputy Ambassador to the UK in Colombia. 
Each workshop began with stakeholder engagement dynamics using Mentimeter, an interactive survey software. Then trainers delivered a climate change basic knowledge presentation titled "The truth in 10" by the Climate Reality Project and a presentation on the International policy context for decarbonization pathways and their importance by The Climate Group which included zoom polls to test participants understanding. This was followed by a presentation on Colombia's Long term Strategy 2050 by the Ministry of the Environment. After a break, The Climate Group staff provided a presentation on the process to develop decarbonization pathways and a presentation on how to develop a long-term vision.  These two events were complemented by a live panel made up of Bogota's Advisor to the Municipal Environment Secretary who shared Bogota's experience prioritizing actions and the city's motivation to develop a pathway on Bogota's Climate Action Plan. Both workshops followed the same agenda. May 26 workshop was attended by the 11 secondary state governments and the May 27 workshop was attended by the 5 main beneficiary states. Attendance on May 26 was 234 participants and on May 27, 486 participants from 16 Colombian states.
Result_Title: Online workshops provided to enhance skills of relevant decision makers of 16 department governments for long-term vision for a decarbonization pathway
Description: Two (2) online workshops on pathways frameworks and long-term vision setting (primary and secondary beneficiary departments), which will be 3 hours each. The workshops will include: Pathways Framework Presentation, E2050 Presentation, Vision Presentation, Case Study by Guest Speaker. It is the same workshop done twice. The departments will be divided into two groups to have a manageable audience. Expected attendance: 500 total participants (250 per workshop) from 16 Colombian departments.

Project: Proposal of reform to the public policy and legal framework of territorial planning in Colombia in order to comply with the Paris Agreement
Description_new: Part 1 of the report presents the urban extension and change in land use for municipalities with more than 100,000 inhabitants. An Atlas with the urban footprint was generated with the analysis of 70 municipalities and 10 agglomerations which contains the general view of the evolution of the urban footprint through the last 30 years of the main municipality and its neighboring municipalities. Part 2 of the report contains the relationship between deforestation trends and changes in land use compared to local land use regulations for municipalities of Yopal, Tumaco, Florencia, Cartagena del Chairá, and San Vicente del Caguán. All the results of the analysis will be consolidated in a book that will be presented in November 2021 and the draft pages of Output 1 will be available by the end of June 2021.
Result_Title: Urban Extent Growth and Land Use Change Report
Description:
A report on Urban Extent Growth and Land Use Change will be produced with two sections: 1) A comprehensive report on urban land-use municipalities with more than 100,000 inhabitants. This report is a quantitative diagnosis that compares urban footprint projections included in the POTs (or Plans for Territorial Planning, acronym is in Spanish) along with the growth experienced by cities in the last 30 years; 2) The second section of the report will be produced on the relationship between deforestation trends and land use changes compared with the land use regulations in place (forest reserves, national parks, POMCAS or Plans for the Management of Hydrographic Bodies, indigenous reservations, and POTs) for Yopal, Tumaco, Florencia, Cartagena del Chairá, and San Vicente del Caguán.
Both sections of the report and their preparatory materials (e.g., inventory of the planning instruments for the municipalities analyzed) will be hosted on a sub-site within Fedesarrollo's website.

Project: Scaling up rural electrification via capacity building to public and private actors
Description_new:
April 22, 2021 (Q2 2021) - International Earth Day, GGGI, the Ministry of Mines and Energy (MME), the Institute for Planning and Promotion of Energy Solutions for Non-Interconnected Areas (IPSE) hosted the virtual and public webinar “Working Together for Universal Access to Energy in Colombia” broadcasted live on the MME's youtube channel. The webinar had high-level speakers such as Minister of Mines and Energy, Diego Mesa, GGGI President & Chair, Mr. Ban Ki-moon, and the British Ambassador to Colombia, Colin Martin-Reynolds CMG. 
The objective of the webinar was to:
1) Raise the country ownership of rural electrification support initiatives being delivered by the project. Topics such as the main challenges and opportunities to the global access of energy in Colombia, ways to boost rural electrification, and the role of the private sector in projects of rural electrification were addressed.
2) Discuss the advances and validate the objective, target audience, delivery modality, and content of the “Certified Rural Electrification Project Developer” course. The webinar presented the progress in the development of the course and a set of interactive questions via the MENTI platform to validate the objective, target audience, delivery modality, identified capacity gaps, and content of the training program for the “Formulation and structuring of rural electrification projects with renewable energies”. 
3) Promote the exchange of ideas, lessons learned, and innovative business models around private sector contribution to rural electrification. In the first block of the webinar, there was a panel discussion on the challenges and opportunities of global access to energy in Colombia. Presentations were delivered by representatives of the public and private sectors, including the Director of IPSE, the Director of Electrical Energy of the MME, the Group of Strategic Execution of the Extractive Sector of MME, and the Director of Innova Solar Colombia. 
The event had 230 participants. The video has 1,394 views to date via GGGI´s Facebook page and MME's Youtube site. According to the survey conducted during the event, 76% of the audience came from the public sector and 24% from the private sector.
Result_Title: Webinar with high-level speakers to raise country ownership of rural electrification initiatives, collect feedback, and promote exchange of ideas and lessons learned
Description: Delivery of one (1) webinar with high-level speakers, such as MME's Deputy Minister, IPSE's Director, and Mr. Ban Ki-Moon (8th Secretary-General of the United Nations), and current GGGI President & Chair. The webinar will serve to 1) Raise the country ownership of rural electrification support initiatives being delivered by the project, 2) Discuss the advances and collect feedbacks on the “Certified Rural Electrification Project Developer” course, and 3) Promote the exchange of ideas, lessons learned and innovative business models around private sector contribution to rural electrification. The event is targeted to MME, IPSE, and subnational entities.

Project: Scaling up rural electrification via capacity building to public and private actors
Description_new:
The Subnational Rural Electrification Working Group was officially initiated on May 15, 2021 with 17 participants (13 men and 4 women) from four subnational territories (Antioquia, Meta, Putumayo, and Chocó). In the first session, there were presentations regarding the objectives and outputs of the project, an overview of the content for the virtual course of "Formulation and structuring of rural electrification projects with renewable energies" and activities such as Mentimeter surveys and questions.
The second working group session was held on June 30, 2021, with 70 representatives (43 men and 27 women) from 19 subnational territories. This second session consisted of knowledge exchange on the financing mechanisms for rural electrification projects, including mechanisms to access funding from FENOGE, FAZNI, and the royalties system.
The Subnational Rural Electrification Working Group was established to facilitate the sharing of best practices and lessons learned among subnational entities. As of June 30, 2021 the Subnational Rural Electrification Working Group has 70 members from 19 departments.
Result_Title: Working group established to convene target sub-national entities
Description:
Establishment of working group(s) to facilitate sharing of best practices and lessons learned among subnational entities. Subnational entities face common challenges and capacity gaps but have limited, if any, opportunities to share knowledge and build on each other experience. The working group(s) will be established under the framework of IPSE's ongoing engagement strategy with subnational entities and will be managed by IPSE after the project implementation period.
Target: At least one (1) working group established.

Project: Proposal of reform to the public policy and legal framework of territorial planning in Colombia in order to comply with the Paris Agreement
Description_new:
On June 10, 2021 (Q2), the webinar "30 años de cambios del uso del suelo en Colombia" (30 years of land-use changes in Colombia) was broadcasted through the different Fedesarrollo social media platforms (Facebook, Twitter, Youtube) in which the results for the Atlas of Urban Expansion and Land-Use Change 2020 were presented, along with analyses and main conclusions from the study. The event had a duration of 2.17 hours. 70 people registered before the event, but there was an audience of 526 people during the webinar. The video has 321 views on Fedesarrollo's YouTube channel to date.
The webinar had the support of Camilo Andrés Quiroz Hinojosa, Director of Urban and Territorial Space, of the Ministry of Housing, Cities and Territory, and Juan Nicolas Galarza Sánchez, Vice Minister of Environmental Planning of the Territory, of the Ministry of Environment and Sustainable Development, who also made relevant presentations to the topic addressed by the project.
Result_Title: Urban Extent Growth and Land Use Change Event
Description:
The Urban Extent Growth and Land Use Change Report will be delivered through the publication of the study, explanatory materials, and all final data in an event hosted by Fedesarrollo and NYU’s Marron Institute via webinar. The webinar will be 1,5 hours approximately to maximise viewership. 250-300 participants are expected, and 1,000 views of the recording at Fedesarollo's YouTube channel.
The event would be targeted at the Municipalities with populations of +100,000 inhabitants (those included in the report: Yopal, Tumaco, Florencia, Cartagena del Chairá, and San Vicente del Caguán), which are deforestation hot spots. Also targeted at the National Planning Department (DNP), Colombian Ministry of Housing, City, and Territories (MVCT), Colombian Ministry of Environment and Sustainable Development.

Project: Expanding the Colombian Climate Asset Disclosure Initiative (CCADI)
Description_new:
[PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT Q1-2021]
The first Tools Webinar, out of three, was held on March 18, 2021. The theme of the event was: The Financial Implications of Climate Change. Perspectives and Tools for Addressing Climate Change. 
In the webinar, a total of 20 companies (35 people), corresponding to 7 entities from the financial sector, including banks, pension funds, insurance companies, the central bank, were connected in the specific space to present the climate risk tool.

[PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT Q2-2021]
Two webinars were delivered during Q2 2021. The first one was delivered on May 27, 2021. It was a Thematic Workshop on Regulatory trends in the financial risks of climate change and the response from the financial sector which aimed to increase capacities of the financial sector on national and international trends regarding regulation to manage financial risks related to climate change. It had the perspective of both the entities that apply the norms and those that will offer the titles. The event had two sections. The first one was an open webinar through YouTube with 118 attendees. It covered the theoretical context of climate change and information disclosure (TCFD), along with the challenges and opportunities to create regulations to include climate change risks. It also included a panel discussion which concluded that: 1). There are many entities have advanced out of conviction and investment strategy; 2) The joint work between investors and issuers is key, but it remains a challenge; 3). Thematic investments are improving. The second section of the webinar was a private discussion about the Colombian regulation of the financial sector. The main conclusions were: 1) One of the main challenges is to integrate climate risks into traditional risks management systems; 2) The sector is ready to report information, but there may be challenges to acquire depth in the information disclosed; 3). The sector feels that although this issue is of great importance, the regulator is demanding changes at a very high speed. 
The second webinar was delivered on 24 June 2021. It was the second tools workshop on the Financial Risks of Climate Change. It included two breakout rooms to train the attendees on the CCADI and CDP tools to manage climate change risks. 35 people attended this second webinar. One of the suggestions to the CCADI tool included the possibility to measure the ‘financial costs’ if the risks eventually occur.
Result_Title: Series of skill enhancements workshops for capacity building and knowledge sharing between public and private asset owners in Colombia and the UK
Description:
Due to the complex nature of climate change and the lack of installed capacity needed to manage risks and opportunities, asset owners require additional training to kick-start and scale up actions towards emissions reduction. For this, the main training activities will take place:
 1). Thematic Workshops: Number of workshops: Two Workshops (2021-Q2 and 2021-Q3)
Type: Virtual conference, through platforms such as Teams or WebEx. They will be recorded and available at CDP Education platform to any additional interested public. 
Target: Directed at private funds, banks, pension funds, insurance sector companies and real sector companies. It is expected that at least one participant from 10 organisations attend.
Content: Climate change risks and opportunities (in April 2021) and Reporting practices under TCFD (in June 2021).
In general, we are hoping to enroll company representatives that will attend all the modules. However, missing a specific session will not affect the attendees overall performance.
Duration: 2 hours each workshop

2). Strategic Meeting with UK organisations:
Number: One meeting to be delivered on 2022-Q1.
Type: Bilateral meeting to take place in the same UK peer mission.
Target: Strategy discussion of CCADI staff  and UK organizations with experience in similar projects (ShareAction and ClientEarth)
Duration: 2 hours 

3). Tools Workshops:
Number: Three (3) Workshops to be delivered on 2021-Q1, 2021-Q2, and 2021-Q3.
Type: Virtual conference, through platforms such as Teams or WebEx. The workshops will be on the use of tools or the use of CDP´s and CCADI's tools  (March, May and July ).
Target: Directed to institutional investors (pension funds and insurance companies). It is expected that at least one participants from 5 organisations attend.
Duration: 2 hours each workshop
