Project: Sustainable Tourism Enhancement Project - Phase 2: Boosting conservation and emissions reduction through tourism and technology
Description_new: [PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT 2021-Q2] First training on acoustic monitoring to 16 nature tourism organisations and land owners of forest protected areas. The main subjects were: 1) The concepts and details associated to the implementation of acoustic monitoring; 2) The expected impact on tourism; 3) The introduction to biodiversity and monitoring, and technologies to be implemented. The beneficiaries of acoustic monitoring training are located in Meta, Casanare, Cauca, Putumayo, Valle del Cauca and Chocó.
Result_Title: Trainings to local nature tourism organisations on acoustic monitoring system
Description:
10 organizations involved in the community based monitoring process will receive training in:
(1) Deployment of the offline devices ("Edges") and the real time monitoring-acoustic sensors ("Guardians") that will monitor the ecosystem soundscape at selected locations, offering important information in biodiversity data, and illegal activities (logging, poaching). (2) The Rainforest Connection Arbimon platform for continued use of the data for more species modeling and in-depth analysis, biodiversity presence over time, and tracking 15 specific species, among others. (3) Illegal activities alerts on the platform. (4) Utilization of the AI models in the platform for understanding how specific species are faring in their land, empowering them to take action to improve presence. 
The goal is to empower hosts with this technology so that they can see how biodiversity is faring on their land. Acoustics are an excellent way to truly understand how communities' ecosystems are being affected on a large-scale that is not possible with any other type of monitoring. Empowering local people with the tools scientists use to understand species communities will inspire pride and expand local knowledge. 
This system will build off of and expand local knowledge, resulting in real-time, automatic tracking of the most critical species in Colombia in addition to the soundscape as a whole. This is an excellent measurement of how conservation practices are impacting the ecosystem and can also be used to guide changes in management plans. 
This training process will include 1 visit by the Rainforest Connection team and a remote training program with the Rainforest Connection Team. Beneficiary organisations will have 4 hours  of training for at least 1 person from 10 organisations. 
Quarterly progress will be provided.

Project: City of Johannesburg Electric Vehicle Readiness Support
Description_new:
The EV Infrastructure Needs Assessment presentation evaluates the impact of electric vehicles on the City's electricity grid. To understand the infrastructure needs, realistic EV uptake scenarios were developed using a vehicle transport model. These scenarios were then workshoped with relevant city officials. These EV uptake forecasts were then translated into infrastructure needs. The presentation documenting the infrastructure needs was developed for City staff. The presentation includes
- Electricity demand forecasts (kWh) and capacity demand forecasts (kW) for City of Joburg
- EV charging requirements (no. of chargers and where they need to be)
- Network requirements and where network strengthening will be required
Result_Title: CoJ EV Infrastructure Needs Assessment
Description:
A presentation documenting the infrastructure needs will be developed for City staff. Infrastructure needs will include:
- Electricity demand forecasts (kWh) and capacity demand forecasts (kW).
- EV charging requirements (no. of chargers and where they will need to be).
- Network requirements and where network strengthening will be required.

Project: Building the Green Hydrogen Economy (GHE) Just Energy Transition: Co-creating a Just Labour Transition through the TVET College System in South Africa
Description_new: On 11 May 2021, SAIIA hosted an online visioning workshop with 37 females and 40 males from the Department of Science and Innovation, SAREBI, Sasol Limited, Eskom, Mintek, CSIR, Energy Wand Water SETA, TIPS, SANEDI, uYilo eMobility Programme, The Palladium Group, HySA Catalysis, Bambili Advisor, South African Local Government Association, Blueprint Consulting, DHET, Toyota SA Motors, UK PACT, EWSETA, Engie Hydrogen, British High Commission, University of Cape Town, NBI, Bophelo Impilo Development Centre – BIDC, KPMG, Anglo American, Environmental Affairs, Sasol Foundation, Stellenbosch university and HyPlat..The agenda covered the following : The South African Hydrogen Society Roadmap, Understanding the Green Economy Market and Business Model, Technical and vocational training for the Hydrogen economy, the energy secretariat and green skills transition, skills planning and learning programmes in the hydrogen economy, futures literacy and systemic innovation in the GHE Just Labour Transition. This workshop is the 1st of 2 workshops that will establish/strengthen a Hydrogen Economy Network that sensitizes key industry players to the potential of the hydrogen economy.
Result_Title: Visioning workshops for public-private-partnership dialogue: 2-hour training workshop on the use of strategic foresight, futures literacy, and the Three Horizons methodology
Description:
1st visioning workshop for public-private-partnership dialogue: 2-hour workshop on the use of strategic foresight, futures literacy, and the Three Horizons methodology:
This workshop is the 1st of 2 workshops that will contain a 2-hour segment  for about 20 people that sensitizes key stakeholders on the use of strategic foresight, futures literacy, and the Three Horizons methodology to co-create preferred South African Just Labour Transition futures that imaginatively captures the values and ideals of all stakeholders and ensures the successful implementation of the Hydrogen Society Roadmap (HSRM) and input into the South African Renewable Energy Masterplan (SAREM). It is set be completed in Q2 2021.

2nd visioning workshop for public-private-partnership dialogue: 1-day workshop to review and improve the co-created preferred South African Just Labour Transition futures: This 1-day workshop with primary and secondary beneficiaries will enable mutual understanding of the various needs of targeted stakeholders on the GHE and their ability and responsibility to help shape a JLT and JET together.

Project: Supporting livelihoods through Ecotourism Routes for Forest and Peace.
Description_new:
[PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT - Q1 2021] 
MARKETING AND ADMIN WORKSHOP #1: During the first entry to each territory, an introductory workshop to destination marketing and administration for community ecotourism was delivered. It was highly practical and interactive, with various subgroups activities. The first part of the workshop talked about the importance of understanding community marketing (as opposed to individual marketing) and highlighted the benefits of ecotourism for the community (versus focusing on the individual). The second part of the workshop spoke about the principles of marketing, and how these reflected in the user journey when dreaming, booking, experiencing, and sharing a touristic destination. Finally, all the activities that derive from the marketing and administrative roles were discussed and listed, and each person selected 3 roles or tasks they thought would have some experience and knowledge to support the overall marketing task. This allowed the project to observe where there was more knowledge, and the challenges to support in some aspects like the administrative roles, that will need to be supported during the year.

The attendees to these workshops were the people selected in the Marketing Working Group. In Perijá, 9 people attended (2 of them women). In Quinchas, 19 people attached (11 of them women). 

[PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT Q2 -2021]
MARKETING WORKSHOP # 2 (TARGETS AND ACTION PLAN). 
Perijá: During June 23 and 24, 2021, the Marketing Working Group's learnings were focused on how to segment clients and project the tourist services. Skills were discovered and strengthened in the marketing and customer service process. The workshop included an introduction to social media, how to publish and how to sell through them, along with the progress of the design of the marketing plan. The participants were very active and participative. Learning by doing keeps the dynamics active in space.
Quinchas: The second marketing workshop with the communities of Las Quinchas was developed at Pizarra-Boyacá on the 18 and 19 of June. The purpose of the workshop was to introduce the marketing group to basic concepts of marketing such as niche market, products, marketing strategy, and digital channels. The idea was to help the participants to identify what target markets they should consider approaching, what needs and interests do these niches have, which of their products respond to their preferences, what messages are appropriate or effective according to what they are looking for, and what channels should they consider to communicate those messages. In the framework of the workshop, an Action Plan was created. It included deadlines, the budget required, leaders, activities to be developed, and success criteria. 
During the workshop, the participants were open-minded and willing to learn and to participate. The conversation was fluid, and they were pointing out good ideas about the topics being discussed and the challenges and opportunities they have. However, there is a risk that they forget or do not consider all the explanations given, hence, it is necessary to do a recap on the next Workshop to evaluate if they truly have kept in mind all the key messages.

MARKETING WORKSHOP # 3 (WEBSITE ADMIN AND USE AND SOCIAL MEDIA)
The training aimed to teach communities to build their own website from scratch in Wordpress. They learned about the basic structure of a website (header, content, footer), basic knowledge of SEO and how content shows itself in different devises (computers, cellphones, etc). The second day, they worked in a practical exercise in a computer (in groups) to learn how to effectively use the different tools and ways to build their own website. This was then applied to the current projects' websites that were created last year, so they appropriated these tools. The final stage of the workshop focused on content creation, especially for social media. A practical exercise was done to learn how to write effective copy that invited the traveler to visit the region, highlighting the main attractions, and pairing the text with an attractive photo or video. The participants were very excited with the content of this workshop, and felt engaged with the practical groups activities.
Result_Title: Community workshops to enhance the capacity of the communities in Quinchas and Perijá to use marketing tools with allocated responsibilities
Description:
Training composed of 7 workshops per region to enhance capacities to use marketing tools delivered to the Marketing Working Group (MWG) established with the communities of Quinchas and Perijá. MWG will be composed around 5-8 people per region. Topics of the workshops include:

Marketing Workshop 1. Topics include:
a) Collaborative working; 
b) Introduction to  marketing.

a) Website, Wordpress, Blogs

c) Content and messaging: focusing on experiences that inspire customers

Marketing Workshop 5 about Sales training to be delivered in Quinchas. Topics include:

b) Working with Online Travel Agents: what are OTAs and which is best for these communities (Airbnb, Viator, Travelingspoon, etc). Legal issues, pricing, operational issues, management of bookings.

Duration of workshop: 1 day per territory
Expected date: 2022 Q1

b) Finalise Content Plan. 
Feedback and follow up with both communities.

Project: City of Johannesburg Electric Vehicle Readiness Support
Description_new: A comprehensive Briefing Note has been developed titled "Managing EV Uptake in the City of Joburg". The briefing note draws on a comprehensive modelling effort by the SEA team to understand the impact of EVs on Joburg's grid. The briefing note proposes a suitable way forward for City Power (and other municipalities) to deal with EV uptake on distribution grids.
Result_Title: Registration process proposal for private EV chargers
Description: Based on experience in South Africa municipalities on registration of small-scale embedded generation, the project will develop a guidance document that proposes a registration process for EV charging infrastructure, in order to assist CoJ and other  municipalities in implementing such a process to encourage the rollout of infrastructure by private entities.

Project: Building the Green Hydrogen Economy (GHE) Just Energy Transition: Co-creating a Just Labour Transition through the TVET College System in South Africa
Description_new:
TVET Gaps Analysis Report to assess the structural skills training capacity constraints within the TVET college system and lack of alignment with industry skills needs. The objective of the research was to develop a profile of what the current nature of skills required is for the South African Hydrogen Economy (HE) overall, with special focus on Green Hydrogen Economy (GHE) for the future; the current ability and capacity of the TVET system to supply these, assess the gap and provide high level recommendations for intervention where required. The key findings are:  
• As a supplier of technical vocational skills, the South African TVET system is not ready and does not currently have the capacity to provide GE or 4IR skills and training to the level that will be required for the HE or the GHE along the value chain. Current TVET programmes are insufficiently responsive to the needs of industry and the needs of the learners to find viable employment.
• Skills required for the HE as it stands are similar to those needed for industrial chemicals and gases production, storage, and distribution and the TVET system currently does not meet industry needs. There is limited to no on-the-job experience made available to learners and work/life skills are not adequate. Some lecturers have inadequate skills and qualifications as well as limited or no experience with the industry and very limited support is provided to students.
• Skills needed for the GHE are similar to those needed in the HE, but their application in the workplace is not necessarily similar and different content (curricula) and on-the-job exposure is required. At the primary level, some skills will be transferable with additional content and on-the-job training. However, as the value chain progresses downstream, the level of different content and training needed increases significantly.
• Future skills needed will be directly linked to 4IR skills throughout the value chain from the process of primary production through to logistics and complex downstream design and manufacture.
• The gap between the ability of the TVET system as it stands to meet industry needs currently, is typically very large. The implication is that it may be necessary to repurpose TVET architecture as well as systematically review how the system operates. In many cases, industry is dissatisfied with the quality and quantum of graduates. If the supply system itself does not improve in relation to industry demand, even new training content and skills development processes will not be sufficiently helpful to bridge the gap.                                         The following are the recommendations made:                                                                                                                                   •Develop a green skills (including the GHE) Master plan for South Africa. 
•Set up a system of co-planning between industry and TVET colleges at the local level, where hydrogen activities are and will be located. For example, close to SASOL, at outlet ports, and so on. 
•Consider accessing international Green Funds (grant) for the set-up and implementation of a just transition reskilling programme focussing on vulnerable workers and communities. Set up a green skills fund with clear and transparent governance focussed entirely on green skills development (and the GHE skills required) and implementation. 
•Set up a senior private sector led and driven working team (firms and DHET) to review the TVET system in terms of international best practice relevant to green skills development and determine how the system could be redesigned to meet needs, as well as attempting to quantify and qualify skills needed and to ensure collaborative planning into the future. 
•Begin a process of inserting GHE skills needs and priorities into national skills policies and strategies, as well as into the national education system and the sector skills plans for the Sector Education and Training Authorities (SETAs). 
•Urgent TVET budget review is proposed. 
•Step up current efforts to develop improved GHE training and development at the TVET level, and scale them up and focus them. Continue to implement emerging skills training and development in partnership with the TVET college system, in partnership with announced programmes (Sasol, Anglo American and Toyota for example). 
•Content additions to STEM education should be designed and included in curricula, and vocational institutions need to systematically evaluate the generic STEM skills on offer as well as content specific to the hydrogen economy. There should be an immediate focus on incorporating digital skills into all TVET college curricula. 
•Develop a compulsory programme for on-the-job exposure in RE, hydrogen, and FC production for lecturers, potentially via exchange agreements with countries which are further along the production path.
•Consider a post TVET STEM qualification in the short term. There is potential for partnerships with private TVET institutions and other PSET entities.
•	Consider the need for the design and implementation of pathways to clean energy production, jobs, and work at the community level. Potential for pilots in coal mining communities could be prioritised and reskilling implemented using material developed for TVET.
Result_Title: TVET Gaps Analysis Report to assess the structural capacity constraints within the TVET college system and lack of alignment with industry needs
Description: The special report will provide a high-level assessment of the current nature and quantum of curriculum and training offered by the Technical and Vocational Education and Training (TVET) College System that would be useful to the Green Hydrogen (including grey hydrogen applications where relevant) economy in South Africa, with a specific focus on industry gaps per sector (transport, mining, power generation, industrial and manufacturing processes and building/construction) and how to overcome these

Project: Driving the green agenda through aligning SA's climate-related financial disclosure with best practice
Description_new: DNA Economics produced 54 fact sheets and one introduction sheet. The purpose of these fact sheets is to provide a view of climate related practices and disclosures from the largest companies on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange (JSE) using publicly available data.  This will enable meaningful engagement and decision-making between stakeholders within the asset management and pension fund industries, including companies and funds, industry associations, regulators and standard-setters on material climate-related financial risks and opportunities. Some fact sheets will be incorporated into training sessions with the various beneficiaries and will be used as case study examples to transfer best practice and learnings on company-level climate-related financial disclosure.  The companies covered included : AbINbEV;ABSA,African Rainbow Minerals, Anglo American Plc, AngloGold Ashanti, Arcelor Mittal SA limited, Aspen Pharmacare Holdings Limited, BAT, BId Corporation, Bidvest Ltd, Capitec, Clicks Group Limited, Fin Richemont, Coronation, Discovery, Distell Group Holdings, Exxaro, Fristrand, Glencore, GoldFields, Grwothpoint Properties Limited, Harmony Gold Mining , Impala Platinum Holdings, Investec Plc, Liberty Holdings Limited, Mediclinic, Mondi, Mr Price Group Limited, MTN, Multichoice, Naspers, Nedbank, Northam Platinum, OM Limited, Pepkor Holdings, Prosus, PSG Group Limited, Remgro, RMB Holdings, RHM, Sanlam Limited, Santam Ltd, Sasol Limited, Shoprite, Sibanye Stillwater, South32 Limited, Standard Bank Group Ltd, The Foschini Group Limited, The Spar Group Limited, Tiger Brands, Vodacom, Woolworths,
Result_Title: South Africa  Climate-related Financial Disclosure Fact Sheets
Description: 50 Fact sheets summarizing the CFD of 50 JSE-listed companies that represent a cross-section of highly invested companies.

Project: STRAPSA - Shifting the transport  paradigm  for South Africa
Description_new:
A training manual was produced by Nelson Mandela University for training interventions on electric vehicles. The manual introduced the project, Shifting the Transport Paradigm for South Africa (STRAPSA), project team, uYilo electric mobility programme. The training material is split over two days. On day one the team will provide an introduction to electric vehicles and electric transportation Under introduction to EVs, the following topics were covered : why are EVs needed? Impacts of the status quo, the road to correcting the impacts of the status quo, history of mobility, mobility today, transitions to electric mobility, driving an EV : efficiency, costs and emissions, EV safety and Debunking the myths about EVs. Under electric transportation (road) : the following topics were covered , 2.1 EV ecosystem, electric vehicle landscape, private vehicles, micro mobility for marginalised and vulnerable communities, fleet vehicles and public transport (road).

On day two, the team will provide an introduction to electric vehicle charging infrastructure , electric vehicle landscape, private vehicles, micro mobility for marginalized and vulnerable communities, fleet vehicles and public transport
Result_Title: Training Manual for two-day training intervention on electric vehicles
Description: Content and material, covering the following topics, is produced: Public transport (road); fleet vehicles government and industry; private vehicles; micro-mobility for marginalised and vulnerable communities; charging Infrastructure; electric busses; publicly accessible chargers; ancillary services from electric vehicle fleets.

Project: City of Johannesburg Electric Vehicle Readiness Support
Description_new: PARTIALLY ACHEIVED: Q1 2021: 1 day online session with key staff from departments of climate change and air quality, electricity & transport. The workshop aim was to provide an overview of the Johannesburg's EV readiness Support Programme and the local context in relation to electric vehicle development, including existing policies and programmes at the national and local level. It also provided an opportunity for each department to align this project with their department's goals and work plans. It also provided an opportunity to align with the national Department of Transport's Green Transport Strategy.  Total of 20 participants, 15 male, 14 female, and 1 gender not recorded.
Result_Title: Four capacity building sessions with CoJ EV steering committee and relevant national stakeholders
Description: Four online capacity building sessions with key staff from relevant City departments, which provides an update of project progress and learnings to date, but also provide a platform for discussion / guidance. As such, national stakeholders may be invited, topic dependent. The sessions aim to ensure continued buy-in from all relevant stakeholders, alignment with City goals, while also acting as a knowledge-exchange and problem-solving hub. As such, this will be a flexible space that will include topics, as they arise, which may not fall neatly within other project activities / outputs, but has been highlighted as a need as the project progresses.

Project: City of Johannesburg Electric Vehicle Readiness Support
Description_new: A learning exchange split over two 2-hour sessions with the aim to provide the City of Johannesburg and City of Cape Town the opportunity to share experiences on the implementation of electrical vehicles. The first session took place on the 23 March 2021 and was attended by 21 people (10 male, 11 female) and covered an overview of Cape Town's EV work. The second session took place on the 25 March 2021 and was attended by 22 people (13 male and 9 female), dived into the details of Cape Town's EV energy demand forecast. Detailed inputs were given by the City of Cape Town EV team and robust discussion took place to enable the desired learning exchange.
Result_Title: Two EV learning exchange workshops between City of Cape Town and City of Joburg
Description:
Two EV learning exchange half day to full day workshops between City of Cape Town and City of Johannesburg. The duration of the workshops depend on availability and agenda. The purpose of the first workshop is to build Johannesburg staff capacity on policy / project levers / methods of EV implementation / support through knowledge-sharing on learnings from EV work undertaken by Cape Town, specifically (but not limited to) the EV Tariff Briefing document, their solar-powered EV charging stations, EV buses and EV fleet pilot.
The purpose of the second workshop is to align the EV approaches of Cape Town and Joburg in order to influence policy and regulation. This workshop will further build Johannesburg staff capacity on building EV charging infrastructure. This workshop will also serve as a platform to compare modelling results.
The expected staff that will be trained are from the following departments at the City of Cape Town and City of Johannesburg : Sustainable energy markets, distribution network development, enterprise & investment, air quality, transmission system development, electricity generation and distribution , electricity department , transport and urban development ,environment and infrastructure services department.

Project: City of Johannesburg Electric Vehicle Readiness Support
Description_new:
1 day online session with stakeholders from City of Cape Town, City of Johannesburg, City Power, CSIR, Department of Transport, Eskom, Stellenbosch University 's Power Systems Research Group and uYilo. 18 participants attended (10 male and 8 female).
The aim of the workshop was to outline the city's role in electric vehicle uptake and charging infrastructure rollout based on current research and have the invited stakeholders and SEA to share their  relevant research on the grid impacts of EVs. 

The presentation given by CSIR Energy Centre focused on national EV grid impact, while Eskom discussed their e-Mobility project with Stellenbosch University's Power Systems Research Group explored EV hosting capacity on MV (medium voltage) and LV (low voltage) networks. uYilo and the City  of Cape Town focused on enabling EVs in South Africa and Cape Town EV framework respectively. 

The agenda covered the following : key roles played by the City of Johannesburg , key research findings around EV uptake , charging behaviour, charging impact, charging infrastructure requirements, smartification and city ownership , and regulations.  The session included robust debate about best strategies to mitigate EV grid impacts on City Power's grid. City Power's capacity and knowledge was vastly increases.
Result_Title: Capacity building workshop with City Power tariff team on tariff setting for EVs
Description: The workshop with City Power staff and NERSA representatives will draw on an EV tariff review and aims to build staff capacity to inform the determination of the City's EV tariff.

Project: Accelerating high-quality growth in China’s Green Bond market and supporting post-COVID green economic recovery
Description_new:
An one-hour discussion between CBI and the Chinese green bond investor community, focusing on the implications of China's carbon neutrality target on green investments, followed by a post-event blog published on 22 June 2021 

Target audience: Green bond investors both international (Blackrock, AIIB,etc.) and Chinese (China Industrial Bank, BOC, ABC, Huaxia Bank, Harvest Fund Management, etc)
Result_Title: Creation of ‘first movers’ to spearhead an investor-led initiative to phase out refinancing of fossil fuel companies.
Description: A survey-based research to assess investor appetite and preference in the green fixed-income markets, followed by two networking webinars on promoting investor appetite and showcasing green projects. Creation of a group of “first movers” to establish/strengthen climate-related networks among green bond investors, underwriters and issuers between Chinese and international market, and to enhance the capacity and influence of this group of practitioners in the making of policy agenda and market decisions that have implications on expediting the reduction of carbon emissions.

Project: Accelerating high-quality growth in China’s Green Bond market and supporting post-COVID green economic recovery
Description_new:
PARTIALLY ACHIEVED: 

A capacity-building workshop is hosted for CBI's approved verifiers in greater China. 24 attendees altogether with 14 F, 7 M and 3 not stated. Objective was to share experience on Financing Credible transitions (entities, activities and assets need to make from today’s high greenhouse gas emissions to levels commensurate with meeting the goals of the Paris Agreement.)
Result_Title: Climate Bonds Assurance Roundtables
Description:
Host of quarterly Climate Bonds Assurance Roundtables for the 17 of CBI's Approved Verifiers in China (e.g. EY, PwC, Deloitte, CCX, Lianhe Equator etc) who served as a primary green bond verifier in China. The attendees are expected to be in the range of 15-20, and the workshops will last for 2-3 hours.

The Assurance Roundtable is to provide a collaborative platform for Chinese green bond verifiers and prospective verifiers to share first-hand experiences and discuss the principles, approaches and practicalities of the Chinese and international green bond standards and certification scheme, in order to enhance capacity. The CBI team will also present on the progress of industry standards for climate bond certification, other regional/intl standards, and the key findings of the CBI issue papers.

Project: Promoting green recovery by championing the power of disclosure, transparency and UK-China collaboration
Description_new: CDP has completed a Gap Analysis Report that assesses progress that key companies have taken to align business practice to the TCFD. This includes a description of TCFD, and data extracts of assessing the readiness of companies in disclosing in line with the TCFD recommendations.
Result_Title: Report of gap analysis of disclosure status against TCFD alignment of Chinese members of China-UK Pilot group.
Description: Gap analysis report following technical support to pilot companies and subsequent  gap analysis of disclosure status (and quality) of pilot listed companies against TCFD alignment.

Project: Promoting green recovery by championing the power of disclosure, transparency and UK-China collaboration
Description_new: CDP has completed a research of readiness of Chinese listed companies and FIs for TCFD-aligned disclosure, the report will be launched formally on 29th June at CDP web, download will be available.1 Uploaded is draft Chinese Version submit (EN version will be uploaded at the end of July).
Result_Title: Assessment report of readiness of Chinese listed companies and FIs for TCFD-aligned disclosure
Description: Assessment of readiness of Chinese listed companies and FIs for TCFD-aligned disclosure, and dissemination of key findings with  policy makers, investors and companies.

Project: Operationalising Energy Performance Certificates in South Africa
Description_new: The final report (titled NBEPR Functional and technical specification, and reporting protocols) builds on the functional and non-functional NBEPR requirements first discussed in the previous report (NBEPR User needs, functionality and technical outline, data management and governance policies report) and details the technical specifications to which the NBEPR must be built in order to meet the functional and non-functional requirements. These technical specifications also form the user acceptance criteria for the NBEPR. Further, guidance is provided on the design of the NBEPR database (the robustness of which is key to facilitating data interrogation and reporting, which in turn is expected to inform climate related reporting and policy making) and a number of additional system requirements, including requirements for meeting the needs of people with disabilities. The document is intended to allow for the SANEDI appointed subcontractor to develop a NBEPR that meets user needs and best practices identified in the prior reports.
Result_Title: Policy recommendations for the  National Building Energy Performance Register (NBEPR) delivered to enabling environment actors
Description: The policy recommendations developed will contain a set of practical interventions to ensure wide adoption of EPC mechanisms across both the public and private sector in South Africa.

Project: Capacity building for green investment and the Green Investment Principles (GIP)
Description_new:
Baseline assessment report to provide an overview of green finance development in Central Asia to evaluate the development progress and regional best practices in Mongolia, Kazakhstan, and Pakistan, as they have achieved notable progress in regulatory framework and accumulated experience in market practice. The analysis suggests while green finance has taken off in Central Asia, it is still at a preliminary stage. The report identifies several challenges with green finance development (including: lack of systematic regulatory policy, limited institutional coordination, lack of enforcement of environmental disclosure, and gaps in climate related risk management), and provides recommendations in response to these challenges. 

Beneficiary: Financial institutions, government departments, industry organizations, and project owners in Central Asia, as well as NGOs, academic research institutions, etc.

Date of release: End of March.
Result_Title: Green Finance Research Report for Central Asia
Description: Baseline report to discover the current state of green finance in Central Asia and help project’s stakeholders better understand the regional opportunities for green investment and financing. It will also combine the expertise of GIP members and pre-existing tools (e.g. green project database) with original analysis to develop a financing gap analysis and roadmap for Central Asia.
Implementor: Beijing Institute of Finance and Sustainability

Project: Sabah Renewable Energy Rural Electrification Road Map
Description_new:
ACHIEVED:  30 Field Researchers and 43 Field Research Assistants trained as the original core audience (plus 13 other consortium staff) and deployed with guidance documents and three research schedules.
We have trained more people than our target of 60, so that we have additional and reserve staff for deployment if and when needed in particular locations.  This field work is difficult and sensitive, not all field researchers will prove able to manage the typically complex situations on the ground.  Flexibility enabled us to continue training whatever the status of the MCO.  

55% of the Field Researchers/Assistant Field Researchers trained are female.  

 In partnership with KPLB we were able to brief all the relevant District Officers and Assistant District Officers about the project and (with a bumpy start) to develop protocols with them around the communications and protocols for site visits.  Some District Offices also supplied valuable data for project planning.  By 30th June 2021 field teams had visited 40 villages identified under the Demand Map (Output One) to undertake the project portfolio data gathering.  25 Village profiles, 57 Focus Group Discussions and 19 Pre-Feasibility studies were undertaken in these 40 villages by 30th June 2021.  Trial analyses have been undertaken of this first set of data to improve our internal protocols and data management systems.  This work is ahead of schedule, and would have been even more advanced if it had not been for the re-application of MCO-SOPs and the reluctance of some villages to receive visitors during pandemic times.  Our team have done what they can including taking COVID-19 tests, and when possible vaccinations, before field work, and other measures to build trust.  The strategy of training local people from within the target districts is assisting with access, but PACOS is also obliged to innovate a “call-center” approach to data collection in areas where we are not currently allowed to visit.  The goal of 200 Villages profiled is scheduled for completion in October 2021.  Field visits are documenting that many villages are partially electrified, using personal, private or public systems mostly solar and diesel generator.  A more nuanced assessment of levels of electrification will therefore need to be developed for Sabah to understand the demand profile and project portfolio.
Result_Title: Field research training and deployment to develop village data profiles
Description: The project will train 60 members of marginalised indigenous communities in documenting, analysing and reporting data on their own needs of importance to the Road Map and project planning process. The structure of training will depend on MCO regulations, but we anticipate blocks of formal training (in-person or remote, followed by on-the-job mentorship). Trainees will be deployed as 30 Field Researcher/Community Organizers and 30 Field Assistant Researchers to detail demand, capacity and potential supply options in 200 villages in their home areas to generate data about contemporary demand, launch a project stream and build awareness and demand for electrification with renewable. Currently, almost nothing is known about non-electrified communities upon which to design the Road Map, identify priority project suites and to connect technical feasibility studies with socio-economic and management issues.

Project: Distilling the JET in South Africa: Harmonizing conflict and seeking opportunities
Description_new: On 3 June 2021 TIPS hosted an 2 hour long online workshop titled "Development dialogue : key priorities and challenges for a Just Transition in Emalahleni and Steve Tshwete programme'   .The key speakers were from the Mo Ibrahim foundation, Vukani Environmental Justice Movement in Action (VEJMA),  Chemical, Energy, Paper, Printing, Wood and Allied Workers' Union (CEPPWAWU), Environmental and Waste Management Directorate of  Emalahleni municipality, Minerals Council South Africa and SouthSouthNorth. The audience consisted of 8 non-binary/prefer not say, 116 males and 150 males. The panel was asked how communities can get involved in just transition. The CEPPWAWU speaker indicated that trade unions would likely support renenwable energy if it could be shown to them practically how coal mining workers will still have jobs as the country makes the transition. The VEJMA speaker highlighted the negative social and health impacts of coal mining in these municipalities. The speaker from the Environmental and Waste Directorate of the Emalahleni municipality annouced that the draft climate change strategy will be submitted to the council for approval on 04 June 2021.
Result_Title: Public workshops - the exact topic/agenda is TBC
Description: A series of three public workshops will be held with local stakeholders to foster collaboration and share evidence, relevant to the JT in Mpumalanga. The workshops will target government departments, state-owned entities, private sector, labour unions, and civil society and community based organisations, and research organisations.

Project: Harmonisation and capacity building for green finance in Belt and Road Investments
Description_new:
PARTIALLY COMPLETED: 

"On 24-25 June, we held the first of two training sessions with Chinese financial institutions focused on building awareness and capacity to deal with climate risks, disclosure, and overseas investments.

The training was attended by representatives from some of China’s most influential financial institutions, including the Bank of China, the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, the Export-Import Bank of China, the Silk Road Fund, the China Export & Credit Insurance Corporation (Sinosure), the China Agricultural Bank, the China Construction Bank and Ping An Insurance, as well as officials from China’s MEE.

Speakers included prominent names in the sector of green finance, including Dr. Ma Jun, China’s most prominent expert on green finance, Prof. Wang Canfa, an expert on environmental law, as well as Dr. Christoph Nedopil Wang, Dr. Wang Yao, and ClientEarth’s Chief Representative in China, Dimitri de Boer. 

The workshop was highly successful in terms of promoting the outcomes of this project. The participants demonstrated that their institutions were highly aware of the issue of environmental risks in overseas investments, and are searching for ways to deal with the problem. During the workshop many constructive exchanges took place, with the representatives of the financial institutions actively participating, offering their views and learning from others.   The most successful segments were the interactive parts, including a mock-up case study of a hydropower project that ran into major problems."

Among the participants to the workshop were 29 men, 41 women, and 13 participants for whom we did not collect this information.  Unfortunately we failed to collect precise data on the gender of all the participants, but we will do so in the future workshops.
Result_Title: Training workshops with key financial institutions on new environmental risk mitigation systems
Description:
Two 2-day training workshops with more than 50 relevant participants on topics such as climate risk, disclosure, and the operationalisation of the GIP and GDG, enhancing their awareness and capacity of applying these new environmental risk mitigation systems. 

The focus of the training may be slightly different from first workshop as above, and some participants may also be slightly different. The second training will go deeper into certain aspects, and incorporate learning and follow up from the first session.

Project: STRAPSA - Shifting the transport  paradigm  for South Africa
Description_new:
First training intervention : DTIC 
On day one 16 delegates received training on an introduction to electric vehicles and electric transportation (road). Under an introduction to electric vehicles, the following topics were covered:  Why are electric vehicles needed?; Impacts of the status quo; The road to correcting the impacts of the status quo; History of mobility; Mobility today; Transitions to electric mobility; Driving an electric vehicle: efficiency, costs and emissions; Electric vehicle safety and Debunking the myths about EVs. Under Electric transportation (road) the following topics will be covered: Electric vehicle system ecosystem; Electric vehicle landscape; Private vehicles; Micromobility for marginalised and vulnerable communities; Fleet vehicles and Public transport (road).

On day two 18 delegates received training on electric vehicle charging infrastructure. The following topics were covered An introduction to electric vehicle charging infrastructure; Publicly accessible chargers, Electric busses and Ancillary services from electric vehicle fleets. 

Audience : Senior Management within the Industrial Development Division: Green Industries; Automotive Sector. Senior Staff within the Industrial Development Corporation (IDC); Senior Staff within Invest SA; Senior Staff within International Trade Administration Commission (ITAC).

Second training intervention : Western Cape government 
On day one 21 delegates received training on an introduction to electric vehicles and electric transportation (road). Under an introduction to electric vehicles, the following topics were covered:  Why are electric vehicles needed?; Impacts of the status quo; The road to correcting the impacts of the status quo; History of mobility; Mobility today; Transitions to electric mobility; Driving an electric vehicle: efficiency, costs and emissions; Electric vehicle safety and Debunking the myths about EVs. Under Electric transportation (road) the following topics will be covered: Electric vehicle system ecosystem; Electric vehicle landscape; Private vehicles; Micromobility for marginalised and vulnerable communities; Fleet vehicles and Public transport (road).

On day two 21 delegates received training on electric vehicle charging infrastructure. The following topics were covered An introduction to electric vehicle charging infrastructure; Publicly accessible chargers, Electric busses and Ancillary services from electric vehicle fleets. 

Audience : Senior Staff within the Western Cape Government and Western Cape Local Government (City of Cape Town). Two Graduates in Training working for Western Cape Government. One Student working for Western Cape Local Government (City of Cape Town)
Result_Title: Seven 2-day training workshops  with personnel (key decision makers) from various national departments
Description: Seven 2 day training workshops with key decision makers from the National and Provincial Department of Transport, National Department of Trade, Industry and Competition, National Department of Environment, Forestry, and Fisheries, National Department of Mineral Resources and Energy, National Road Agency, National Treasury, and Eskom Holdings. The training will be conducted online and is expected to have 20-30 people in attendance for each. Day one will cover the following topics on e-mobility: Public transport (road); fleet vehicles -government and industry; private vehicles; micro mobility for marginalised and vulnerable communities. Day two will cover the following topics on e-mobility and charging infrastructure: electric busses; publicly accessible chargers; ancillary services from electric vehicle fleets. Hiten Parmar, Edem Foli and Julien de Klerk will be providing the training.

Project: Sustainable Tourism Enhancement Project - Phase 2: Boosting conservation and emissions reduction through tourism and technology
Description_new: [PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT 2021-Q2]  The Marketing Strategy was created. It contains the tactics and actions that will be carried out for the commercialization of 10 destinations, while giving visibility to conservation initiatives. After doing a general diagnosis and a DOFA and PESTELT analysis to prioritise the destinations to be commercialised, the following 10 destinations were selected: Bahía Malaga, Puerto Nariño, Casanare, Río Guejar (Meta), Nuquí, Inírida, La Macarena, Mocoa - Orito, Ipiales and Cali surroundings. The analysis also included collection of travelers' perceptions through surveys. The implementation of the marketing strategy started in May and has been active for three months. Up until 30 June 2021, total sales were of COP $429,331,151 (GBP 78,000 approx) in Villaviencio, Putumayo, La Macarena, Guainía , Nuquí, Río Güejar and Puerto Nariño.
Result_Title: Commercialization strategy and high-quality audiovisual content that showcases the tourism experiences, hosts conservation efforts, impact of GHG emission reduction, and the results of the monitoring and measurement pilot program
Description:
Design and implementation of a commercialization strategy to showcase the environmental impact of the initiatives and critical climate-related content to engage and bring awareness to travelers and other donors. It includes developing high quality audiovisual content for 10 destinations, with the following results:
- 4 destinations with a 1-minute video, a 30-second video. and 50 photographs.
- 6 destinations with a 5-minute video, a 30-second long video, and 50 photographs.
The audiovisual content will not only showcase the most important and significant destinations and nature highlights, but will also showcase the community, their conservation efforts, and monitoring results. This content will be used for the marketing and positioning strategy, but will also be shared with the local organizations for their own marketing.

Project: The development of a Green Economy Cluster organisation to support Mpumalanga's role in the validation, implementation and follow-on research of the South African Renewable Energy Industry Masterplan (SAREM)
Description_new:
This document provides a breakdown of the current progress of the South African Renewable Energy Masterplan. It provides a consolidated view of stakeholder inputs towards workstreams for identified plan actions/levers. This is an important step in ensuring that the SAREM and its recommended actions are pragmatic, sensible and will lead to the desired outcomes. This record of emerging workstreams and potential levers forms a reference for discussion to prioritize focus and refine and validate implementation plan elements.

Six specialist focus groups were held to formulate a shortlist of opportunities, market bottlenecks, required drivers and potential levers in a specific focus area draft SA Renewable Energy Masterplan. 

(i) Industry reference focus group - energy planning (sector coupling) :  A focus group workshop was held on 7 April 2021. This workshop was lead by GreenCape and The Council for Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR). The discussion focused on unlocking the significant opportunities associated with the hydrogen economy, hydrogen export potential and sector coupling of heat and transport to the power sector. The list of proposed levers was categorized
into Policy and Markets, Technology and Infrastructure, and Financing.

(ii) Industry Reference Focus group – Electricity planning :As part of the process for defining a long list of levers for the electricity planning focus group, a focus group workshop was held on 7 April 2021. This workshop was lead by GreenCape and Meridian Economics.  In general, the key levers that surfaced from the workshop were focused on stimulating the increased uptake of renewable energy in South Africa’s power sector. Levers were categorized into four main focus areas: market development and regulatory reforms, technical advancements to the transmission network, the role of policy and potential financial interventions that could be implemented.

(iii) Industry   Reference Focus group – Just Transition: As part of the process for defining a long list of levers for the Just Transition focus group, a focus group workshop was held on 8 April 2021. This workshop was lead by GreenCape and Trade & Industrial Policy Strategies (TIPS). As part of an overall, broad strategy and mix of measures, the renewable energy sector can make a positive contribution towards a just transition on at least three key levels: the rollout of renewable energy-based electricity generation can provide a source of economic activity and employment through the deployment (project planning and design, procurement, construction/installation, operation and maintenance) of large-scale power plants and small-scale systems; renewable energy technologies provide a platform to enhance the access to modern energy services by all, including through increased new ownership models; and the development of the renewable energy value chain, from the mining and beneficiation of minerals to the manufacturing of parts, components and systems, to the recycling of components, can generate economic activity and employment in the country.

(iv)Industry Reference Focus group – Transformation :As part of the process for defining a long list of levers  for the Transformation focus group, a focus group workshop was held on 8 April 2021. This workshop was lead by GreenCape and Letsema.  Some of the key challenges that have hindered the participation of marginalised groups are as follows: limited access to finance by Black people in ownership deals; high costs of Black equity financing; the limited flow of benefits in  community ownership trust structure and here is no strategic development of Black people for management role


(v)Industry Reference Focus group – Skills : There were several skills development desktop studies initiated before and around the publishing of the Integrated Resource Plan 2010, which culminated in the intervention of creating the South African Renewable Energy Technology Centre (SARETEC), an initiative of the Department of Higher Education & Training (DHET) and the National Skills Fund (NSF). SARETEC was mandated to undertake targeted skills training of operations and maintenance skills for the wind and solar renewable energy sector. SARETEC, hosted by the Cape Peninsula University of Technology (CPUT), aimed to train local skills to replace foreign technicians working on South African renewable energy power plants after the implementation of REIPPPP( Renewable Energy Independent Power Producer Procurement Programme) Round 1 and 2 projects. The impact of SARETEC on the local skills landscape was measured by subsequent research like the Tracer Studies undertaken between the GIZ and Altgen Consulting. More recent skills development studies with the onset of  Bid Windows 3 and 4 included  the following: GreenCape Green Economy Skills Audit, Altgen, 2019 Report;. An Overview of the Employment Implications of the South African Power Sector Transition, Based on research undertaken by Meridian Economics on behalf of SAWEA, July 2018;A Just Energy Transition in South Africa, Socio-economic needs and the positive impacts of a future low carbon economy. Compiled by RES4Africa in partnership with CSIR & ERM, 2020;Future skills and job creation through renewable energy  in South Africa, CSIR Renac,  IET, UfU & IASS Potsdam,  March 2019;SAPVIA Solar PV Industry Jobs Report, Literature Review, CSIR on behalf of SAPVIA, April 2021.Some of the main outcomes from the above studies include that the lack of certainty in the REIPPPP nullifies any large scale predicted skills shortage in renewable energy. South Africa can significantly boost employment by increasing the share of renewables with jobs concentrated in the services, construction and manufacturing sectors and the bulk of job creation being in the high-skilled labour group. Consideration should be given to a reskilling hub to take advantage of the opportunities renewables offer across the energy value chain to mitigate job losses. Jobs vary substantially between the asset construction and O&M phases, with more jobs in the construction phase than the O&M phase for solar PV; hence continuous rollout of new PV projects is critical to creating new skills and jobs. Finally, the employment implications of the power sector transition are highly complex and dynamic and validating suitably complex and diverse analysis to enhance user understanding of the skills required is a critical aspect.

(v)  Industry Reference Focus group – Export: a  thriving local renewable energy manufacturing sector requires South Africa to be a competitive exporter of renewable energy components, systems and services. The limited focus on driving industrialization and the gap in the REIPPPP process means that South Africa may have missed “window the opportunity” to be a base for exporting to other markets (including future renewable energy projects in Africa), especially as other emerging economies have stepped into the renewable  energy (manufacturing) space in the interim. At the same time, stakeholders have indicated that an export market (i.e. additional demand for components, skills and services) may be required to provide economies of scale for local manufacturing in South Africa. Additional insights are needed to understand and deconstruct this opportunity.   There have been several instances of South African manufacturers of key components exporting locally manufactured components. In particular, Jinko Solar, Tenesol, and Art Solar have  all been exported. GRI, the tower manufacturer, also exported temporarily to keep the factory productive. Many others chose to close down manufacturing facilities as the export opportunity was not sufficient to enable them to continue (e.g. SMA, AEG, SunPower). The global market for Renewable energy components is growing rapidly year on year. This means that new manufacturers can compete in a growing market. Global dynamics like antidumping duties and various domestic manufacturing policies in big manufacturing markets (like China) have big impacts on the competitiveness of locally manufacturing components. Between preferred bidder status and financial close, the IPPO allows a portion of the bid tariff to fluctuate with the exchange rate – this creates
a possible lever for locally manufactured projects and the amount of the tariff that can float on the global risk be decreased round by round.  

Taking into account the SAREM outcomes, the drivers and barriers that have been identified by industry, labour and government stakeholders, ten SAREM workstreams have been proposed in chapter 6 of the report: market consistency/certainty/growth, industry transformation; the development of a local content policy; input materials cost and availability; trade support/export support to access regional opportunities; system readiness; new entrant support/incentives/barrier; local manufacturing competitiveness; creation and support of a skills hub (local use and export skills); and just transition hotspots.

Subject to no impediments to  the process arising, the draft plan is expected to be reviewed and the final plan adopted for implementation by the industry, government, labour and social partners during the 2021-2022 financial year.
Result_Title: SAREM Validation Report
Description: A validation of the SAREM with the appropriate stakeholders. This is an important step in ensuring that the SAREM and it's recommended actions are pragmatic, sensible and will lead to the  desired outcomes.

Project: Driving the green agenda through aligning SA's climate-related financial disclosure with best practice
Description_new:
Produced two reports, the first " Climate-related Financial Disclosure in South Africa", introduces climate-related financial disclosure and motivates for better and more disclosure by South African institutions. It is intended as a resource for readers who want to motivate for disclosure within their institutions. In summary the report covers why climate-related financial disclosure is useful, introduced the Task force on Climate-related Financial Disclosure, described the main types of climate-change related financial impacts, reviewed climate-related financial disclosure trends internationally, considered the local factors influencing disclosures and described the current state of climate-related financial disclosure. 

The second report, “Climate-related disclosures for financial institutions”, provided a review of international best practices for climate disclosures relevant to South African financial institutions. The report discussed (i) the landscape of global climate-related disclosures and best practices, (ii) reporting in  line with TCFD recommendations and details of TCFD disclosure for financial institutions, (iii) relevant metrics and methodologies, (iv) best practices for scenario analysis and (v) local context for South African financial institutions.
Result_Title: Trends in Climate-related Financial Disclosure Report: What Does it Mean for South Africa
Description: Trends in Climate-related Financial Disclosure Report: What Does it Mean for South Africa: Report showcasing international trends and best practice in CFD, and distilling what this means for SA. Result from a desktop review of international trends and best practice in CFD.

Project: Driving the green agenda through aligning SA's climate-related financial disclosure with best practice
Description_new: PARTIALLY ACHIEVED: Quarter 2 2021: Produced a 16 page special edition publication, Climate-related financial disclosure-aligning South Africa to global best practice, was published on Atleha-edu website summarising the learnings from the 53 fact sheets and reports on climate-related financial disclosure in South Africa and climate-related disclosures for financial institutions. It introduced South Africa-UK PACT programme and climate risk (describing physical and transition risks and impacts on policy, reputation and markets). Moreover, climate risk analytics for sustainable investment, an overview of climate risk and investment, climate risk and scenario analysis, climate risk and corporate reporting were covered with a Financial Sector Conduct Authority (FCSA) Guidance Note on sustainability of investments, and investment opportunities presented the transition to low-carbon economies were discussed. The publication ended with a short questionnaire.
Result_Title: Online publications of learnings from report and factsheets on Climate Finance Disclosure in South Africa, including audio visual products.
Description:
Production of three knowledge products on Climate finance disclosure: 

1.Online publication of learnings from report and factsheets on Climate Finance Disclosure :16-page digital online publication summarizing the learning from the knowledge products developed previously

2. Audio-visual products to accompany CFD report and factsheets:4 voice pieces and 1 video content piece summarizing the content and message of the Climate Finance Disclosure report and factsheets

3.Infographic-focused summary document with state of play, insights, learnings and progress that can be shared at COP26.

Project: The development of a Green Economy Cluster organisation to support Mpumalanga's role in the validation, implementation and follow-on research of the South African Renewable Energy Industry Masterplan (SAREM)
Description_new:
As South Africa undergoes several different transitions, there is a need for an inclusive social order that brings labour, government, and business into an agreement. This inclusive social order is the role of the social compact, whereby each partner commits to implement concrete interventions to realise specific economic objectives with a sector, e.g. job creation. To ensure key stakeholders are targeted, GreenCape have produced three stakeholder maps. The first is government and state-owned entities, which includes two key government departments with direct support from three others: the Department of Mineral Resources and Energy (DMRE) (responsible for the oversight of the plan’s development). 

The second is the renewable energy industry stakeholder mapping, which is split into industry groupings for the social compact and value chain groupings for industry. This includes the original equipment manufacturer, local renewable energy manufacturers, project developers, investors, members of South African Photovoltaic Industry Association, and members of South African Renewable Energy Council. The third is the organised labour stakeholder mapping. There is currently no Renewable Energy labour union which means different workers across the value chain are represented by different unions. Labour unions included in the map are: The Federation of Unions of South Africa, Congress of South African Trade Unions, Solidariteit, Chemical, Energy, Paper, Printing, Wood and Allied Workers' Union, National Union of Mineworkers, and National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa
Result_Title: SAREM Social Compact Mapping (industry champions of change)
Description: A mapping of the appropriate stakeholders to be involved in the social compact of SAREM. Having the correct set of stakeholders signing the social compact is vital to the long term success of SAREM, as these stakeholders will be the ones making the commitments to deliver on the plan.

Project: Climate Transition Pathways
Description_new:
Q3 2020
CEO Launch event: The CEO launch event was held on 28 July 2020 to much public interest and support from the South African business community. This CEO launch event milestone was held and attended by amongst others, the CEO’s of the country’s two most carbon intensive companies as per CDP – Eskom and Sasol. A sizeable number of CEOs from leading companies and key industry bodies have been recruited to champion the project. Leveraging the convening power of the NBI and BUSA (Business Unity South Africa). At the time of reporting 24 CEOs of listed companies agreed to be CEO champions, as well as the Johannesburg Stock Exchange and various industry bodies. On-boarding of more CEO’s is ongoing.
Q4 2020
CEO Champions Advisory Meeting: Pathways for the electricity sector to "Net Zero" by 2050. This meeting took place on 15th November 2020 and counted with the participation of 49 representatives from a diversity of companies, of which 20 were women. The meeting introduced the core project team, explained the scope of work for the project and its contribution to the South African climate targets and the just transition. The project explained the focus areas of the project in 2020 and provided an overview of the analysis and findings for the electricity sector, their modelling approach, the role of the just transition, and its links to broader social and economic agendas in the country. The feedback from the participants was positive overall.
Q1 2021
CEO Champions Advisory Meeting: Business Action for Sustainable Growth. This meeting took place on 24th February 2021 and counted with the participation of 34 representatives from a diversity of companies, of which 13 were women. The purpose of the meeting was to share key findings from modelling exercises in the electricity sector and petrochemicals sectors and the initial review for just transition for coal value was completed. The agenda also covered achieving a net zero power mix, decarbonizing South Africa’s petrochemicals sector and the role of gas in energy transition in South Africa. The meeting ended with a discussion of the next steps which would be work in agriculture, forestry and other land use and transport sector.
Q2
On 01 July 2021, NBI hosted a CEO champions meeting. The objective of the meeting was to discuss the international policy context and process related to COP26, introduce, "Business statement on the Just Transition", provide an overview of progress and latest findings, present planned publication series and share the "CEO Guide".
Result_Title: CEO Champions Advisory Meetings
Description: A series of advisory meetings with the CEO champions aimed at identifying the pathways to "Net Zero" by 2050 in Petrochemical, Mining, and Electricity sectors. The first meeting will be the launch intended to inform a wide range of intended stakeholders about the project and its aims.

Project: Paving the Way for Setting Ambitious GHG Emissions Reductions in the Private Sector to enhance the National Climate Change Policy
Description_new:
[PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT - Q2 2021]
Two workshops took place:
1.- A workshop for the staff of Procuraduria Federal de Proteccion al Ambiente (PROFEPA), which focused on giving an introduction to the SBT initiative (SBTi) and how this initiative could be linked to the Programa Nacional de Auditoría Ambiental (PNAA).
2.- A workshop with Comisión Nacional Bancaria y de Valores (CNBV) with 6 sessions about: (i) Introduction to the workshop, (ii) Climate change science and Mexico's commitments, (iii) Climate change and the finance sector, (iv) Introduction to the SBTi, (v) Introduction to SBT methodologies for the finance sector, and (vi) Deep dive into the finance sector SBT tools

The third workshop with Comisión Nacional de Mejora Regulatoria (CONAMER) was not achieved during Q2 as there were internal changes to their team. The third workshop is to be held in Q3.
Result_Title: 3 tailored workshops for government beneficiaries on corporate climate action
Description:
Three workshops tailored to consider the needs of the government beneficiaries. The aim of this output is to integrate the SBTi as a complementary tool for regulatory and market instruments aimed at reducing GHG emissions.
Proposed workshop themes (to be explored in more detail with the government beneficiaries): 
a) Available SBTi resources for financial institutions to align their lending and investment activities with the Paris Agreement.
b) The SBTi framework and how it could contribute to enhance the NDC implementation and its transparency through private sector actions, the strengthening of corporate MRV frameworks, as well as the potential synergies with environmental audit programs and the ETS.
c) Incorporating and boosting corporate climate action of small and medium-sized enterprises.
The project expects that each workshop have at least 20 attendees (key staff and teams) from the beneficiary institutions.

Project: Assessment of the greenhouse gas mitigation potential of hydrogen. An implementation roadmap for Mexico
Description_new: The dissemination event took place on June 1, 2021, on the topic "Green hydrogen opportunities for Mexico: An international review of technologies and experiences." The event gathered a group of 127 participants (37% were female and 63% were male). Welcome speechs were given by the British Ambassador to Mexico, a General coordinator from Instituto Nacional de Ecología y Cambio Climático (INECC), and the Executive Director of Centro Mario Molina (CMM). The presentations were given by representatives from CMM, Imperial College London, British Petroleum, Cambridge and World Bank.
Result_Title: Webinar on the opportunities for green hydrogen in Mexico and presentation of the existing technologies and experiences
Description: This dissemination event will present the results from Q1 with materials prepared from the project results. The event will include presentations from actors identified at this stage. This dissemination event is needed so that a green hydrogen network of actors is initiated. Given the current COVID-19 pandemic, this dissemination event will be delivered online. It is expected to have approximately 50 participants.

Project: Assessment of the greenhouse gas mitigation potential of hydrogen. An implementation roadmap for Mexico
Description_new: The report developed is a review of (i) green hydrogen technologies in the energy and industry sectors, (ii) national & international case studies of green hydrogen production projects, and (iii) costs associated with hydrogen generation, storage, transmission, distribution, and end uses.
Result_Title: Review and analysis of state of the art technologies for green hydrogen production and use in the energy and industry sectors
Description: A review of green hydrogen technologies in the energy and industry sectors, national and international case studies of green hydrogen production projects in the previously mentioned sectors, and a map of key green hydrogen actors in Mexico and the United Kingdom.

Project: Consolidation of the Mexican Climate Finance Hub - mobilizing resources to mitigation and adaptation activities and achieve Mexico´s emission reduction goals
Description_new: The briefing developed elaborates on (i) the barriers and opportunities to finance green infrastructure developed by subnational entities in Mexico, (ii) the relevance of private-public partnerships as a mechanism to finance such infrastructure, as well as (iii) the best practices to access financing as a subnational entity in four different stages of developing a project (feasibility, development, and operation).
Result_Title: Briefing for subnational entities on green funding and project finance for green infrastructure
Description: Briefing that elaborates on how to identify the financial vehicle most aligned to the green project or projects subnational entities are aiming to finance, focusing on repayment methods and liquidity sources. The briefing is the result of meetings with at least 14 subnational entities (either states or municipalities) where individuals from the Environmental and Finances Ministries sit together.

Project: Landscape conservation and livelihood restoration in the Mexican ejidal altiplano: the case of Apan, Hidalgo.
Description_new:
[PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT Q2 2021]

Dissemination Event 1 of 3: IP presented the impact of climate change in the Altiplano and the 5 main issues identified in the diagnostic report for each of the following topics: water, soil and biodiversity. There were 4 sessions with 45 participants in total. Participants shared other possible issues with the audience.
Result_Title: Targeted dissemination of products for transparency and information directed towards beneficiaries and local stakeholders
Description:
Series (3) of dissemination events covering main results and documents with local communities (publication of content, distribution of documents, exhibition of project results) and general communication of the project for transparency and information of local actors on progress and activities. This output will include evidence of:
- Dissemination of communications products around the diagnostic report on shared knowledge of the territory’s current and future prospects under climate change
 -Dissemination of communications products around the recommendation report on inclusive and participative governance and funding for nature-based mitigation and adaptation to climate change
- Dissemination of communications products around the action plan report including the results of a collective prioritization of potential nature-based solutions for climate change adaptation and mitigation
Implementor: Eetestudio  (Espacio entre tiempo estudio SA de CV)

Project: Landscape conservation and livelihood restoration in the Mexican ejidal altiplano: the case of Apan, Hidalgo.
Description_new:
The diagnostic report was developed, covering: (i) the definition of land territory of Apan, (ii) its recent history and main socio-environmental trends, (iii) main socio-environmental issues related to climate change (including a climate change prospective scenario, threatened hydraulic resources, soil erosion, disappearance of local biodiversity, governance and inequality issues, and main socioeconomic issues).

In addition, a legal annex was developed. This annex documents the federal and local constitutional frameworks of water and water concessions for Apan.
Result_Title: Diagnostic report on shared knowledge of the territory’s current and future prospects under climate change
Description: The project will start by creating a diagnostic that charts and documents the environmental and socioeconomic state of the Apan altiplano, its main trends, and climate change’s current and potential impacts on a range of natural and man-made conditions relating to water, as well as its impact on both forest sustainability and local livelihoods. The project expects to produce a report containing the detailed analysis, as well as other formats that will be adapted to the concerns of the different stakeholders. This will begin the cultivation of shared knowledge of the territory and of an understanding of short and longer-term impacts of climate change on water and other resources necessary to reproduce their livelihoods.
Implementor: Eetestudio  (Espacio entre tiempo estudio SA de CV)

Project: Strengthening the use of Earth Observation platforms to support the implementation of climate change mitigation goals in the forest and land use sector in three states in Mexico.
Description_new:
IP set up an inter-institutional mapping working group to discuss definitions, criteria, methods and best practices for mapping land cover/use and land cover/use change. The first meeting was held on the May 27th and 31st where CONAFOR, SIAP, ECOSUR and INEGI presented objectives, definitions, classes, inputs, products, processing methods and tools, post-processing and accuracy evaluation of their mapping methods. 
12 men and 12 women participated.

A second meeting was held on the June 10, 2021, where user cases were presented by SEMAHN, FEMEXPALMA, and the state government of Tabasco. Ecosistemas presented a comparative table of methods and classifications. Ecosistemas also demoed an EO Lab application that compared different maps in Chiapas that was set up by ECOSUR.
10 women (28%) and 26 men (72%) participated.
Result_Title: Inter-institutional working group formed between at least three national and six state institutions responsible for agreeing on criteria to monitor the agricultural frontier to monitor progress towards the net zero deforestation goal
Description: Working group formed Federal Agencies (CONAFOR, SADER, SEMARNAT, SEMAHN, SAGIB, SBSCC SEDAFOP, SEMABICC, SDR, FEMEXPALMA ) to agree on key criteria, methods, and institutional arrangements to define and monitor forest and agricultural frontier at the state and national level. The group will agree on the methods and responsibilities for monitoring deforestation and GHG emissions between the agencies.
Implementor: Ecometrica Ltd. (Ecosistemas Consultoría Integral para Soluciones sustentables)

Project: Strengthening the use of Earth Observation platforms to support the implementation of climate change mitigation goals in the forest and land use sector in three states in Mexico.
Description_new:
"Ecosistemas Consultoría completed the draft of the analysis of the platforms, which included a technical analysis and effectiveness evaluation, based on findings from the online seminar on “Geographical Information Platforms and Their Use in Public Policy” (April 28-29th), as well as user interviews and questionnaires for the administrators.

The report was sent to the platform administrators on July 10th, and a final version  was shared with beneficiaries and partners on July 14th. Platforms included in the analysis are SINACIC, MARACC, ECOSUR EO Labs, SAMOF, and Observatorio de la Selva Maya."
Result_Title: Evaluation Report on Climate Monitoring and Mitigation Actions
Description: A report that evaluates the effectiveness of different information platforms to articulate and monitor climate mitigation actions in the land use sector. The report will look at factors such as data inputs, advantages & disadvantages, and barriers to use for each platform, as well as the potential to integrate different platforms. Report should inform decisions of state and national government agencies on which platform to use and the inputs required from each agency.
Implementor: Ecometrica Ltd. (Ecosistemas Consultoría Integral para Soluciones sustentables)

Project: Technical assistance for developing sustainable energy access strategies in Mexico
Description_new:
Puebla:
4-day training with multiple government senior managers and managers.
The final result was to align with the Agencia de Energía with Bienestar so they can start working on an energy access program in the state (Bienestar was already working on this initiative).
Veracruz:
4-day training with multiple government senior managers and managers. On the final day, a plan was set to focus on a few municipalities for the visits so the Agencia de Energía can present the results to a potential funding partner.
Yucatán:
