4-day training with multiple government senior managers and managers. During these sessions, there was an active participation from CFE, and the Agencia signed a collaboration agreement to share knowledge as a result of the workshop."
Result_Title: 4-day workshops with State Energy Agency on designing energy access programs in 3 states in Mexico (Puebla, Veracruz and Yucatán)
Description: The workshops aim is to create materials and resources, and to develop the skills and understanding of senior managers and managers, allowing them to have a better understanding of how energy access programs can be designed to satisfy the end-users needs, whilst being financially and technically sustainable. 12 hours of training in total.
Implementor: Ilumexico (Eres Energía Renovable SAPI de CV)

Project: Strengthening the Legislative-Executive-Stakeholder dialogue on Mexico's climate change and energy goals at the national and subnational levels
Description_new:
[Event 1] A virtual meeting to kick-off of the Joint Collaboration event with participation of legislators from the Commission of Protection of the Environment and Climate Change (CPMACCPEA) in Mexico City’s Congress, the British Embassy, Mexico City Secretary of Environment (SEDEMA), and POLEA advisors.

[Event 2] The virtual event was held for the Participatory Process of Elaboration of a Circular Economy Law Initiative, with emphasis on combating Climate Change in Mexico City. Participation of 3 deputy members from the Commission for the Preservation of the Environment, Climate Change and Ecological and Animal Protection (CPMACCPEA) from the Congress of Mexico City; representatives from the British Embassy, the Ministry of the Environment (SEDEMA), Economic Development (SEDECO) of the Government of Mexico City, international institutions, and civil society organizations.
Result_Title: Two high-level event forums in Mexico City with legislators at the local level
Description: Two high-level events will aim to raise awareness on the relevance of harmonizing Mexico City's Climate Change Law with other sectoral legislation.

Project: Accelerating Fleet-wide electrification of public transport in Mexico City
Description_new: GPS data was collected from the 7 existing Metrobus lines that will be used to conduct energy analysis. The document describes the methodology and variables captured and other considerations for analysis.
Result_Title: Report on GPS data collected for Metrobus lines
Description: GPS data collection (coordinates each second) of the 7 current lines of Metrobus, including the electric buses arriving in Line 3 (Yutong) and Line 4 (Volvo).
Implementor: Dalberg Advisors (Asesores en Desarrollo Dalberg S. de R.L.)

Project: Technical assistance for the implementation of emergent design for active mobility and public space
Description_new:
The guide was developed and contains the following three sections:
- The first section is about general information as prologue and introduction.
- The second section is about 'Territorial management', which includes the following tools: i) to gather information, ii) to consult, iii) to dialogue, iv) to co-create, v) to active interventions, and vi) to communicate. 
- The third section is about 'Communication', which includes tactics, communication media, campaign structure and examples with creativity. In the last section are the references and the annexes with formats.

The publication presents tools to guide the inclusion of priority groups in decision making. It includes 20 additional recommendations to strengthen the tools (i.e. having mixed teams for site visits and considering different timeframes / preparing specific activities for the involvement of children).
Result_Title: Guide for local governments to communicate emergent strategies for active mobility and public space projects
Description:
Guide for local governments to communicate emergent strategies for active mobility and public space projects focused on guiding local governments in the development of their strategies to communicate the projects and to involve minority groups during the development of strategies for active mobility and public space. This publication will have recommendations about inclusive language and graphic design, strategies of approach with the population, territorial governance strategies, etc. 
The output will develop from March to June, and it will delivered in June

Project: Green Finance for the development of Smart Cities in Mexico II, working to accelerate the implementation of low carbon local projects and sustainable development
Description_new: 2 training sessions were delivered to beneficiary cities on the identification and evaluation procedure & methodologies to select projects for green finance mechanisms access. There were 13 participants in total, from the cities of Chihuahua, Hermosillo, Villahermosa and Zapopan, representing NGOs, government, and the private sector.
Result_Title: Training sessions to enhance capacities of city public servants to identify and evaluate potential projects for green finance mechanisms
Description: The trainings aim to create capacities among city public servants for the identification, evaluation and selection of feasible projects eligible to green finance.

Project: Supporting livelihoods through Ecotourism Routes for Forest and Peace.
Description_new:
[PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT 2021 Q2]
From June 21-24th, a culinary tourism course was held in Perijá. It was directed by Jennifer Rodriguez and her team (one biologist and one anthropologist, both empirical cooks). The course was divided in two parts: (1) the importance of costing and portioning, (2) the use of food waste in other food products, such as using banana peel to make vinegar. 
The cooking began by using traditional regional products such as moringa and cilantro in different and innovative preparations like mojos and pestos, as well as different sauces and dips with traditional chilies. Also, other preparations were done that were going to be needed for the next day. The second day of the course was dedicated to creating a complete lunch menu with different options and ways of using traditional ingredients from the people's orchards. 3 main groups of food were developed: i) soups, salads and sides, ii) animal protein (in this case fish), and iii) desserts using the fruits from the region. The audience was highly engaged, empowered, and devoted to their different tasks, and the final result was a variety of delicious, nutritious, healthy, balanced and local, participatory meals, cooked by all the community members (mostly woman) interested in the gastronomic and culinary element of tourism.
Result_Title: Culinary course that incorporates native or traditional ingredients worth showcasing for touristic purposes in Quinchas and Perijá
Description:
1-week trainings per region to enhance culinary skills of the communities to fulfill both tourist tastes and diversify the diets of the communities with healthy nutritious, locally grown food. This will also support the recuperation of traditional knowledge on the use of biodiversity for food supply and to make a connection between healthy ecosystems with useful edible plant species. 
Number of trainees in Quinchas: at least 10 people. Number of trainees in Perijá: at least 10 people.
The trainings will be designed with biosafety protocols in coordination with the communities.
Expected date in Quinchas: 2021 Q3
Expected date in Perijá: 2021 Q2

Project: Adopting New Technology, Mindsets, and Practices to Transform Colombia’s Agricultural Sector
Description_new:
In Q2, the dedicated website was completed. It describes the challenges, opportunity, solution, activities, and why Meta/Colombia.
It is hosted on Rare's website: https://rare.org/program/transforming-smallholder-agriculture/
Result_Title: Dedicated webpage for the project
Description:
Includes project materials such as videos, photos, and testimonials which will be regularly uploaded and provide a more intimate and personal perspective on the project. In addition, there will be a summary of project achievements and other relevant resources that the project generated such as some of the knowledge and communications products above.
Established in Q2-2021 and progress reported quarterly.

Project: Adopting New Technology, Mindsets, and Practices to Transform Colombia’s Agricultural Sector
Description_new:
[PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT Q2 2021]
During Q2, Precision Development (PxD) worked on the integration of the back-end platform, Paddy, and the telecom aggregator’s systems, Sinch (formerly Wavy). The first SMS messages were sent to farmers during June 2021. 
Paddy is a toolkit developed by PxD for building two-way communication platforms with a high degree of automation. In programming terms, Paddy is more like a library than an application. The library contains a set of reusable modules that we can choose to deploy in different combinations for each new service launched. Paddy can run on a variety of backends, for example, SMS platforms, IVR (Interactive Voice Response) platforms, or chatbots on WhatsApp or Telegram. Paddy collects detailed usage data and generates tabular data like that by SurveyCTO/ODK. It is very easy to add randomization to the platform logic for implementing A/B tests or RCTs. Logic can vary based on user data, so different groups of users can be served through different platform configurations and content.
As of June, SMS were sent to a data base of more than 2,000 farmers with agronomic advice on the climate-smart practices that the project is promoting. For the kick-off, a welcome message was sent informing that the service has been developed as part of the UK PACT project, that the messages will be received weekly free of charge, and that the objective is to help improve crop productivity and sustainability. The first set of messages corresponds to cross-cutting practices, starting with soil management. Six topics are being covered in total: i) organic matter, ii) cover crops, iii) erosion, iv) burning, v) soil analysis and vi) fertilization. For each thematic, 12 messages have been delivered. In June, the topic addressed was organic matter with specific aspects on composting: benefits and how to do it.
Result_Title: Ongoing mobile-based technical support to farmers on climate smart agriculture
Description:
Through a mobile technology platform, the project will provide customized and timely recommendations on CSA topics delivered directly to farmers, with the purpose of offering continuous technical support, optimizing the number of farmers to be reached in a cost effective way. The design and set up of the platform include the development of agronomic content, inclusion of gender considerations and application of behavioural strategies. In addition, it includes an assessment on content dissemination, considering available services (SMS, voice) and farmers preferences. Call center agents, once recruited and trained, will collect farmer information and feedback, and provide customized and timely agronomic advice on a regular basis. One A/B test will be carried out to improve the delivery of the digital component of the service.
Target: 2,250 farmers receiving digital agronomic advice on CSA practices 
Quarterly progress will be presented from 2021-Q2.

Project: Accelerating development of new bioeconomy businesses and enhanced capacities for green jobs promotion and increased climate action ambition from policy implementation and integration.
Description_new:
[PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT Q2-2021]
Key advances have been made by prioritizing the actions of the green growth policy's action plan and the sustainable economic reactivation policy according to the following criteria: i. Level of influence or direct impact, ii. Linkage to other actions, iii. Materiality of the action based on the size of the goal and the associated investment amount. 
A report has been developed that details a consultation and assessment of information from different sources such as the Territorial Green Growth Index, the Climate change MRV system, Sinergia system, Sisconpes, Sisclima, and SDG's reporting schemes. The report also provides a detailed assessment of implementation progress and planned activities under the current National Development Plan 2018 – 2022. The project team is currently advancing on assessing at least three interinstitutional working agendas that involve SD´s, Green Growth Policy, and NDC implementation to identify possible recommendations for the upcoming National Development Plan 2022-2026 (activity 5.3). The interinstitutional agendas prioritized are 1. Productive Development Policy 2. National Forest Agenda 3. Circular Economy Strategy 4. Bioeconomy Mission and 5. Comprehensive Climate Change Management Plan for the Mining and Energy Sector - PIGCC.
Result_Title: Low-carbon and green growth recommendations delivered to serve as part of the basis for the upcoming National Development Plan (NDP) 2022-2026 based on the progress of GGP, green recovery, and the 2030 agenda implementation
Description: Recommendation that frames the assessment of the GGP, green recovery, and the 2030 Agenda implementation as technical inputs for the Environment and Sustainable Development Division of DNP to be included in the formulation of the technical document (Bases del Plan Nacional de Desarrollo, or the Basis for the National Development Plan). This output will serve as a fundamental technical input upon which the next National Development Plan will be built, which is led by the National Planning Department and renewed every four years.

Project: Accelerating development of new bioeconomy businesses and enhanced capacities for green jobs promotion and increased climate action ambition from policy implementation and integration.
Description_new:
[PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT  Q2-2021] 
On May 12, 2021, GGGI, SENA and UK PACT held an open and virtual panel discussion on the importance of generating green jobs for the sustainable reactivation of Colombia. In this space, all three parties announced the partnership and the project itself, presenting key expected results. Mr. Ambassador Colin Martin-Reynolds, Ambassador of the United Kingdom in Colombia and Carlos Mario Estrada, General Director of SENA, opened the event, followed by the panel discussion with Andrea Constanza Tibaquira - Curriculum Management Coordinator of SENA, Alejandra Ospitia - Executive Director of FEDEMADERAS, Santiago Briceño - Director of International Climate Finance and Clean Growth Programs of the British Embassy in Colombia, and Carolina Jaramillo, Colombia CR of GGGI. The panel was streamed live on SENA's youtube channel and so far has 1,677 views to date. The panel is a cross cutting result across the development of all three sectorial knowledge networks. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dkNBtkdPwwM

In addition, during Q2, GGGI advanced on strengthening and reinvigorating SENA's Electrical Energy
Sectorial Knowledge Network. The network met on June 2nd to evaluate and validate with key private and public energy stakeholders regarding the profiles of potential students for the Technological Energy Efficiency program. This is especially important considering that part of the role of the Energy Network is to confirm what type of student is required for the program and more importantly, what type of graduate does the energy sector needs as potential employees. The objective was achieved through a 4-hour meeting with different types of interventions, feedback, propositions and comments, as well as filling in an evaluation form.
Result_Title: Three SENA sectorial knowledge networks strengthened and reinvigorated in low-carbon labour force development
Description:
Three (3) SENA sectorial knowledge networks strengthened and reinvigorated in low-carbon labour force development. These networks serve as a forum to enhance sectoral knowledge and ensure that the training delivered matches industry needs, the latest sectoral knowledge is shared, the latest generation of technology is integrated into training and research, and the needs of the labour market are met, thereby contributing to Colombia’s competitiveness and productivity. This output will focus on the following SENA´s networks:

Environmental Network - Includes different topics such as recycling and waste management, water treatment, reforestation, ecosystem conservation among others. Reforestation issues will be covered here with the participation of the National Federation of Timber Industry - FEDEMADERAS, and community-based organizations as the private sector and citizen counterparts.  
This will be developed throughout a series of technical meetings, workshops, knowledge exchange, and guideline documents designed together with SENA and private stakeholders to provide a clear understanding of the sectorial needs and perspectives.

Biotechnology Network. Bioeconomy training program will be developed in cooperation with this network and the participation of private sector counterparts like National Association of Businessmen of Colombia- ANDI, and research centers as Corporación BIOS, Biointropic, BIOTEC, among others).

Electric Energy Network. Energy Efficiency is a priority training program to be developed within this network. We will work with the Colombian Council of Energy Efficiency CCEE in order to receive significant inputs.

Progress will be presented on 2021-Q2, 2021-Q3, 2021-Q4. In 2021 there will be a workshop for all three networks.

Project: Adopting New Technology, Mindsets, and Practices to Transform Colombia’s Agricultural Sector
Description_new: The teaching material for the 90-hour course was developed, containing module contents, slide packs and syllabus. The material comprehends topics on Introduction to Behaviour Change, Local Governance, Leadership Skills, Andragogy, Climate Change and Agriculture, Behaviour Change, and CSA.
Result_Title: Training materials for the 6 module diploma course on Behaviour Change, Local Governance, Leadership Skills, Andragogy, Climate Change and Agriculture, and CSA
Description: Teaching material to impart new skills and bolster a different understanding of what successful extension support entails. Material for the 90-hour certificate, 6 modules (Intro to Behavior Change, Local Governance, Leadership Skills, Andragogy, Climate Change and Agriculture, Behavior Change, and CSA).

Project: Adopting New Technology, Mindsets, and Practices to Transform Colombia’s Agricultural Sector
Description_new:
Four guides on priority practices were developed on the following topics: 1) Guide on micro-organisms, 2) Guide on how to make compost, 3) Guide on how to use agroclimatic information, 4) Guide on soil health. 
Through focus groups with producers and extension workers, it was possible to review and adjust the contents to make them simple and easy to understand, as well as guarantee that the information presented was pertinent and relevant to the type of producer the project is working with. Feedback was also important in the process to make materials more attractive and adjusted to the context of the area.
Result_Title: CSA printed guides and digital tutorials on new agronomic practices addressed to farmers
Description: User-friendly guides and tutorials on priority practices to support agile uptake of new practices. A core component of the Behavior Diffusion Strategy. Social marketing materials make CSA benefits easy to understand, encouraging more farmers to adopt these practices and to gestate a new farming 'norm'. CSA printed guides and digital tutorials on soil health, agro-climatic station, compost, microorganisms, biodiversity and production data records keeping form.

Project: Adopting New Technology, Mindsets, and Practices to Transform Colombia’s Agricultural Sector
Description_new:
[PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT 2021 Q2]
Webinars with municipal mayors, agriculture, environmental authorities, and state-level authorities from five prioritized municipalities (Cubarral, Lejanías, El Dorado, El Castillo, Granada)  were held on the 25, 27, 28, and 31 of May. With this set of webinars, it was possible to present the objectives, main activities, and progress made by the New Technologies Project, practices to transform the agricultural sector in Colombia. Also to discuss the adoption of practices to boost rural development in sustainable ways. These webinars helped to identify the common ground and goals between the project and the participant institutions.
In El Castillo municipality, 11 members of the municipal council participated. At the departmental level, the Secretary of Agriculture, officials from Cormacarena (Noreco), and officials from the Orinoquía's BioCarbono Fund were present. There were 47 participants in total, of which 24 were women (51%).
Result_Title: Working sessions and events to strengthen Authorities network within 5 municipalities on CSA practices and sustainable landscapes
Description:
To strengthen the network with authorities within 5 municipalities, the following activities will take place:
(1) 5 x 4-hour municipal workshops on community shared vision of climate smart agriculture and sustainable landscapes. 1 workshop per municipality (Cubarral, Lejanías, El Dorado, El Castillo, Granada). Workshops on "community shared vision" supplemented with active exchanges cross the 5 municipal authorities build a shared understanding with a short-term action plan to advance implementation of CSA practices. Expected date: 2021 Q4.
(2) 1-day public event where mayors pledge to act as advocates/champions of CSA. Through a public event, mayors pledge as champions and also provide public recognition for "Profe" farmers. Mayors provide public recognition for farmers who join the Profe network and expand CSA practices on their land. Expected date: 2021 Q3.
(3) Webinar with municipal mayors, agriculture, environmental authorities and state level authorities to motivate commitment towards implementation of CSA at landscapes levels. Webinar will generate the space for participants to make a public pledge on their commitment with the project implementation in their municipalities and foster the communication of project progress with the authorities. Expected date: 2021 Q2
(4) Webinar on integrated landscape management with municipal mayors, agriculture, environmental authorities and state level authorities to exchange experience on the implementation of CSA at landscapes levels. Webinar will enable municipal mayors, agriculture and environmental authorities to share lessons learned, feedback and recommendations for the implementation of CSA at landscape levels. Expected date: 2021 Q3

Project: Adopting New Technology, Mindsets, and Practices to Transform Colombia’s Agricultural Sector
Description_new:
During May, workshops with municipal authorities of Cubarral, El Dorado, Granada, and Lejanías were developed. On June 24th, the workshops were completed since the workshop with the Governor's Office from El Castillo was delivered.
Through these workshops it was possible to provide information on behaviour change methodologies, climate-smart agriculture practices, and an introduction to climate change issues, which helped to motivate commitment towards the implementation of CSA at landscapes levels.
The workshops had a participation of 15 attendants, of which 7 were women (47%).
The material, agenda, and attendance registers from the training sessions are available as evidence.
Result_Title: 5 x 4-hour workshops with municipal authorities on behaviour change, climate change literacy, and climate-smart agricultural practices
Description: 4-hour workshop with municipal authorities on i) Introduction to behaviour change, ii) Climate change literacy, iii) Climate smart agricultural practices. 5 workshops, 1 per municipality (Cubarral, Lejanías, El Dorado, El Castillo, Granada) and for state level authorities. Workshops will train municipal mayors, agriculture and environmental authorities on integrated landscape management, climate change literacy and behavioural approaches, generating increased commitment for implementation of CSA at landscapes levels.

Project: Adopting New Technology, Mindsets, and Practices to Transform Colombia’s Agricultural Sector
Description_new:
250 farmers agreements signed (78 with female producers, corresponding to 31%) to cooperate with soil analysis, compost processes, and be part of the training sessions.
1-day training workshop with farmer innovators from the 5 prioritized municipalities on an introduction to climate-smart agricultural practices and climate change with emphasis on i) Soil management, ii) Benefits of composting / how to properly process compost, and iii) Importance of gathering climatic information for efficient irrigation.
The purpose of these trainings is that farmer innovators understand the importance of soil components (chemical, physical and biological) and the relationship between soil and rainwater absorption.
Result_Title: 5 x 1-day training workshops with farmer innovators on climate-smart agricultural practices and climate change
Description:
1-day training workshop with farmer innovators on introduction to climate smart agricultural practices and climate change with emphasis on i) Soil management, ii) Benefits of composting / how to properly process compost, and iii) Importance of gathering climatic information for efficient irrigation. In addition, guidance on how to collect samples for soil analysis will be provided. 5 workshops, 1 per municipality (Cubarral, Lejanías, El Dorado, El Castillo, Granada). 
The purpose of these trainings is so that farmer innovators understand the importance of soil components (chemical, physical and biological) and the relationship between soil and rainwater absorption.

Project: Adopting New Technology, Mindsets, and Practices to Transform Colombia’s Agricultural Sector
Description_new:
Universidad de Los Llanos agreed to collaborate with the development of this 90-hour course. The course had a participation of 48 extension agents total, and in a closing ceremony through a webinar on May 21, participants shared some examples of the social marketing material that they have developed. The 48 extension agents will be receiving a certificate of completion for this diploma course, from which 44% of the total are women. Material from the different sessions of the course on "Changing behaviour tools for sustainability in the agricultural sector" is presented, and training feedback via surveys as well, which are already registered in the training questionnaires in the RMS.
The course helped to enhanced the skills of extension agents and provide tools for them to interact with farmers and offer technical assistance for the sustained adoption of climate-smart agriculture practices.
Result_Title: 90-hour certificate course for extension agents on behaviour change methodologies, andragogy, climate change literacy and climate smart agriculture
Description:
90-hour certificate course delivered to 40 extension service agents ("extensionistas" in Spanish) to equip them with the skills, knowledge, and tools needed to provide effective technical assistance to farmers for the sustained adoption of climate-smart agricultural practices and to provide them with new approaches to enhance more interactive, effective engagement with farmers. 
Target: 40 extension agents trained.

Project: Sustainable Tourism Enhancement Project - Phase 2: Boosting conservation and emissions reduction through tourism and technology
Description_new:
[PARTIAL ACHIEVEMENT Q2 2021] 
First training on community-based ecosystems monitoring to 12 beneficiary organisations located all in the Meta Department, in the municipalities of: Cubarral, Macarena, Mesetas, Restrepo, San Martin and Villavicencio. Each organisation received a 1-hour training session which covered: 1) what is a participatory community monitoring and the process to monitor through selective components (bioindicators and abiotic indicators) and permanent plots; 2) What are conservation agreements, the process to sign one, and the associated benefits.
Result_Title: Trainings to local nature tourism organisations in community-based monitoring of ecosystems
Description:
Train at least one person from 10 nature tourism organisations on community-based monitoring of ecosystems. Each person will receive at least 8 hours of training. Modalities of the training will ideally be 100% on-site, but depending on COVID-19 restrictions, part of the trainings will be virtual. 
Number of training sessions to cover the 8 hours of training will depend on the modalities defined.
Topics in the training include:
1) Flora monitoring
2) Forest replacement dynamics
3) Fauna monitoring
4) Forest structure
Quarterly progress to be provided.

Project: Preparing the public and financial sector for CTR: Capacity building and call to action
Description_new:
Development and designs of content material for the first module of the course: "Understanding and managing the climate transition". 
This module is focused on the principles of climate transition risk and the methodologies existent to assess it. Module I will have 5 sessions with a total of 12 hours of synchronic learning and 12 hours of individual work. The applied methodology will be learning by doing, in order to apply concepts and tools into the diagnosis of climate transition risk in Colombia.
The syllabus and five presentations and facilitator guidelines are developed, showing the content of each session and the methodologies implemented to quantify climate transition risks such as WTW and 2DII methodology.
Result_Title: Novel course material based on the principles of climate transition risk management and the methodologies existent to assess it
Description:
Course material for 12 hour training on climate transition risk principles and methodologies. The course material will be created for virtual training based on learning-by-doing. This course material, based on research and methodologies of 2DII, WTW (ex CPI Energy Finance) and the CFS-Uniandes, includes the syllabus, facilitator guidelines for each session, materials per session (power point, exercise, and reading material).
This course would be targeted to:
-Public sector representatives (Superfinanciera, DNP, BanRep, MADS, etc)
-Financial sector representatives (Fasecolda and insurance companies, banks and financial institutions like Bancolombia)
-Uniandes and other 2 local universities (to be determined)

Project: Supporting livelihoods through Ecotourism Routes for Forest and Peace.
Description_new:
[PARTIALLY ACHIEVED] 
(1). The Marketing Working Group (MWG) of Perijá and Quinchas were established on the 10th of March 2021 and 19th of March 2021, respectively, with high engagement and commitment. The group committed to work together throughout the year to structure the marketing scheme of the destination. In Perijá, the group involves people from the 3 tourism agencies that are committed to working together. There are young people in the groups who are skilled in social media and content development. They know they need to work more in the administrative aspects of marketing. The MWG is made-up of 9 people, where 22% are women (2 in total). 
In Quinchas, since the communities are so far from each other, and many people did not know each other, there is an identified need to work harder to support them in their marketing skills, especially because they are in remote areas and not connected to Wifi. The PDP is committed to working with the communities to make sure they agree on working together to market Las Quinchas as a whole destination. The MWG in Quinchas is conformed by 19 people where 58% are women (11 women).
(2). During Q1, two participative sessions to define the yearly plans with the communities and strengthen the tourism networks were held during the first visits to Perijá and Quinchas between the 8th and 19th of March 2021. During these sessions, there was a kick-off meeting where communities remembered where they left off last year, and presented and agreed on the yearly plan, defining specific dates for the first second trimester of the year. The different groups of people were formed, according to their interest in a specific component of the touristic chain (biodiversity guidance, culinary, home-stays, marketing and admin). The communities in both regions are excited and highly engaged with the continuation of the project, and agreed with keeping the community-agreements on the benefit-sharing philosophy of the project. The initial touristic routes were also discussed and reorganized, and the communities committed to testing them before the next activity occurred. The outcome to agree the yearly plan was achieved in both regions. The attendance to each region and session was: 
Perijá: 
March 9 (La Victoria): 13 people attended (30% women). 
March 9 (Session 1 afternoon in la Jagua): 15 people attended (47% women).
March 10 (morning session): 11 people attended (45% women). 
Quinchas:
March 17th (Nazareth-Altazor communities): 21 people attended (47% women).
March 18th (Betania Quinchas): 15 people attended (53% women).
Result_Title: Series of engagements with communities to strengthen the network to develop tourism in Quinchas and Perijá
Description:
Series of engagements to strengthen two local networks (one in Quinchas and one in Perijá) to develop sustainable tourism in the regions: 
(1) Two Market Working Groups (MWG) established in Quinchas and Perijá. This refers to the group of people that will receive all the trainings, to then lead and implement the marketing activities, strategies and tools. These groups are expected to be of 5-8 people per region. Expected completion date: 2021 Q1 
(2) Two participative sessions (one per region) to define a yearly work plan and schedule for implementation of the project activities, to guarantee coordination and functional role assigning amongst all the beneficiaries and consortium partners. Expected completion date: 2021 Q1.
(3) Two final debriefing sessions to strengthen the tourism network within Quinchas and Perijá. Communities will learn from the one year experience with the project. The debriefing session will be with project partners to acknowledge the learnings and to ensure that their future tourism endeavours involve all the learnings, recommendations, and feedback to move forward. 
It will include a survey for the communities to evaluate the one-year project and to assess the usefulness of the overall process and learnings. Expected completion date: 2022 Q1

Project: Capacity building for green investment and the Green Investment Principles (GIP)
Description_new: PARTIALLY ACHIEVED: Q2 2021 2 day online webinar Green Finance Leadership Program (GFLP) in the context of net zero: inauguration of the GIP Central Asia Chapter. The objective of the training was to enhance environmental risk management capabilities of participants and encourage green investment amongst financial institutions in Central Asia and South East Asia through sharing of international best practice. More than 30 panelist from Kazakhstan, Mongolia, Pakistan, China, and the UK shared their insights on green investments, green taxonomies, environmental and social risk management, and biodiversity. 270 participants attended the webinar (122 male, 147 female, and 1  not recorded).
Result_Title: Green Finance Training Session for Central Asia and Southeast Asia
Description: Two training sessions which will be tailored with local heated topics and market situation for Central Asia and Southeast Asia each. The main objectives of this training session will include: 1) Encouragement of green investment among financial institutions in Central Asia and Southeast Asia 2) Enhanced climate and environmental risk management capabilities 3) Communication among all key stakeholders for sharing the best practice in green finance 4) Tailored regional questions to be answered, such as how financial inclusion help to solve the local social problems or specific high carbon industries (energy, transport) could deal with transition risks. More details on number of training participants and event duration are to be confirmed taking into consideration the latest development of COVID disruption.
Implementor: Beijing Institute of Finance and Sustainability

Project: South Africa Skill share: Hydrogen Society Roadmap (ZA-001a-R)
Description_new:
A narrative summary of the finalised Theory of Change (ToC) and the sub-theories of change for the Hydrogen Society Roadmap (HSR) document was developed setting out the logic behind the ToCs. Advice on the structure of the HSR was provided to South Africa's Department of Science and Innovation (DSI) to better reflect the ToC’s inclusion in the HSR document. The HSR ToC was presented to the HSR Steering Group/DSI on 6 April 2021 to review and confirm the high-level ToC and the sub-ToC. The HSR ToC provides an accessible high-level overview of the objectives for a hydrogen society, including economic, social (GESI), environmental and climate objectives, in line with South Africa’s National Development Plan. It sets out the high-level outcomes which will contribute to these objectives. For each outcome the levers of change required to reach those outcomes are presented with the outputs, activities and stakeholders needed. Subsequently, DSI has incorporated the agreed theories of change and narratives into the latest version of the HSR. This has been shared with all the HSR stakeholders.
 
The preparation of the ToC was kick-started through a series of bilateral consultations with the main stakeholders. Workshops were attended by representatives of DSI, Department of Trade, Industry and Cooperation (DTIC), Department of Mineral Resources and Energy (DMRE), Department of Public Works and Infrastructure (DPWI), Department of Forestry, Fisheries and Environment (DFFE), National Treasury, SANEDI, Energy Research Centre (University of Cape Town), uYilo e-Mobility Programme, Technology Innovation Agency (TIC), North West University (HySA), Unlimited Energy, Trade and Industrial Policy Strategies (TIPS), South African Institute of International Affairs (SAIIA) and KPMG.
 
The ToC journey followed a two-step approach characterised by two workshops. During the first workshop with the Hydrogen Society Roadmap Steering Group (18 February 2021), an initial draft ToC, drawing on the bilateral stakeholder consultations, was presented to attendees for further discussion and refinement  to ensure the HSR’s aims and content were being accurately reflected. This first iteration yielded a high-level ToC prepared along with a set of sub-Theories of Change for each of the six agreed HSR outcomes – energy security, production of hydrogen, manufacture of hydrogen-related products, export of green hydrogen, decarbonisation of industry and decarbonisation of transport. The second workshop (6 April 2021) was held to review and confirm the high-level ToC and the initial sector-focused sub-Theories of Change.
Result_Title: Theory of Change (ToC) for the Hydrogen Society Roadmap (ZA-001a-R)
Description: Building on all the capacity-building work developed by this skill share, creation of Theory of Change (ToC) for the Hydrogen Society Roadmap, with an accompanying report explaining the ToC in detail as well as the anticipated economic, social (including GESI), environmental and climate outcomes from Hydrogen Society Roadmap and how they will be generated. The schematic will provide an accessible high-level overview.

Project: Skill share: Colombia Climate Physical Risks and Financial Stability (COL-001a-R)
Description_new: A team of two green finance skill-share experts, with extensive experience of the Latin American region, supported Colombia’s Banco de la Republica (Central Bank) Financial Stability Department and economists from the Superintendencia Financiera (Financial Superintendency of Colombia) in identifying transmission channels, and then by providing recommendations towards scenario test options to show how physical climate risks affect financial stability in Colombia. The skill-share experts’ final recommendations were to incorporate information about precipitation to assess the impacts of El Nino and La Nina on financial stability variables at the national, departmental and sector (with a focus on energy) levels. This analysis will inform how different insurance and bank business models will be impacted and how their respective responses can improve the organisations' risk management practices. Additionally the results from the different climate change scenarios will be used as a tool to identify physical climate risks (impacts associated with physical damage from environmental disasters) and transition risks (risks associated with the move to a carbon-neutral economy).
Result_Title: Identify transmission channels and recommend scenario test options to show how physical climate risks affect financial stability in Colombia (COL-001a-R)
Description:
Lead discussions with the Banco de la Republica and Superintendencia Financiera to assess climate projections and the available data on transmission risks for Colombia. 
The goal is to create a comprehensive list of possible transmission channels and establish recommended scenarios for how to perform top-down climate stress tests. These will assess the impact of physical risks associated with climate change in the Colombian financial system and help the Banco de la Republica to identify ways to improve, better quantify and assess the impact of climate related risks on the economy and on financial stability.

Project: Thailand Skill Share: Workshop to support Thailand to develop and adopt a cross-cutting policy for the promotion of electric vehicles on Thai roads (TH-001a-R)
Description_new:
The UK PACT programme mobilised two key experts (one roster expert and one representative from the UK Office for Zero Emission Vehicles (OZEV)) to deliver a presentation at a workshop on Electric Vehicle (EV) policy held on 6 May 2021. The workshop was designed to help build and strengthen the case for Thailand to adopt an EV policy and support its development by drawing on lessons learnt from the UK. The workshop was jointly convened by the British Embassy to Thailand in Bangkok, Thailand's Ministry of Energy, and the UK PACT programme led by the UK’s Department for Business, Energy & Industrial Strategy. 

The experts presented on the ‘Lessons learnt from a decade of electric mobility deployment’, and the policy implications concerning the move towards zero emission vehicles (ZEVs). This enabled the Thai government to observe the UK’s experience in formulating its policy to implement its ambitious target to phase out internal combustion engine vehicles. A workshop summary report was created which presented ten key recommendations, next steps for the Thai government, and areas of focus for future work.

The workshop had 55 attendees (including 21 females) across the following institutions: Board of Investment; Department of Alternative Energy Development and Efficiency; Electric Vehicle Association Thailand; Electricity Generation Authority Thailand; Energy Policy and Planning Office; International Affairs Division (Ministry of Energy); Ministry of Energy; Ministry of Finance; Ministry of Industry; Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment; Ministry of Transport; Office of Natural Resources and Environmental Planning; Office of the National Economic and Social Development Council; Office of Transport Planning; PTTPLC; Thailand Greenhouse gas and Management; The Federation of Thai Industries.
Result_Title: Proposed policy recommendations for Thailand's National EV Policy (based on UK best practice) (TH-001a-R)
Description:
A half-day training workshop will take place in early May with members of the National Electric Vehicle Policy Committee (NEVPC) – representatives from the Ministry of Energy, Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Industry, and other key government and private agencies who will help to formulate the Electric Vehicle (EV) policy in the future. The workshop will provide a general understanding of UK EV policy and commitment, policy formulation, the implications for CO2 emissions from transport, and policies and tax based incentives to promote the adoption of EVs.

Following the workshop, a summary report will be created which will present current UK best practice and define the recommended next steps to help Thailand to formulate their EV policy and agree areas of focus for future work. This will help to identify additional capacity building support required to enable Thailand to move forward with their EV policy documentation.

Project: Sabah Renewable Energy Rural Electrification Road Map
Description_new:
[PARTIALLY ACHIEVED Q2 2021]:
Training One achieved: 17 senior staff of the primary beneficiary organisations and 15 members of the Consortium NGOs attended this on-line course over two days that introduced the mini-grid concept in the context of Sabah, with a guest lecture from one of the most successful mini-grid establishment efforts in Indonesia.  

This course was conducted on-line on 29th and 30th June 2021 with 17 senior management staff from the four primary beneficiary government agencies.  53% of course participants from the primary beneficiary agencies were women.  The course included conceptual, experiential and practical knowledge (with a virtual tour of the create space where renewable energy systems are built and taught), and a presentation by Ms. Tri Mumpuni, a leading minigrid energy developer from Indonesia.  

15 members of the consortium participated in these trainings – both as contributors and as learners.  Representatives of UK PACT were also able to introduce the initiative to the beneficiaries and to attend substantial discussions.  The obligation to undertake this training in a virtual on-line environment prevented us from being able to use a field visit to a working micro-hydro grid to achieve a different level of understanding for senior government officials.  A virtual learning environment also made it more difficult for us to understand the reactions of our participants.  We plan the next round of training to be in-person and in the field.  

Total participants on Day One were 32, and on Day Two there were 25.
Result_Title: Two trainings for senior and middle management public officials on renewable energy mini-grids
Description:
The project will conduct two "high-level" trainings for senior and middle management public officials on renewable energy mini-grids:
(1) A two-day introductory workshop on renewable energy mini-grids, with a focus on primary beneficiary organisations (especially KPLB and SESB) so that they are apprised of the technical and institutional issues and understand how they fit into a broader renewable transition globally as well as in Sabah (this can be taken on-line if COVID-19 SoPs require). The content for these course will be designed specifically for this event drawing on past training experiences in Sabah and SE Asia by TONIBUNG and Green Empowerment, as well as internationally (pro-bono support from University of California Berkeley). Preliminary findings from this project will be included where relevant. 
(2) The two online single day courses for the same cohort trained in part one above. This training will focus on explaining the findings of this Consortium’s work within the context of the renewable energy transition for Sabah. 

While the first training will focus on technical issues of the scale and distribution of demand and potential supply options, and the second training will look at the policy and enabling environment issues. These workshops will significantly grow the capacity of stakeholders to contribute towards, understand, critique and socialise the 'Rural Electrification with Renewable' Road Map.

Project: Harnessing Green Finance through Climate-related Risk Management and Opportunities in Malaysia
Description_new:
An industry level workshop has been conducted as part of the wider JC3 Flagship Conference which was held from 23-25 June 2021. The Conference hosted a total of 6,382 attendees from 407 institutions including Board members, CEOs, Senior Management and practitioners, as well as financial institutions’ clients, investees and other value chain players. 

The workshop was structured in three different sessions:
1. The first session was delivered by Joanne Lee (Sustainable Finance Specialist, WWF) in “The role of finance” panel session on 23rd June 2021, from 10.05am - 10.50 am, with a total of 913 attendees.  Joanne was one of three panel speakers including the president of Thailand Stock Exchange, the Secretary General of Ministry of Environment and Water (Malaysia), and moderated by the CEO of Al-Rajhi Bank. The session discussed the role of finance in assisting the transition towards a low-carbon economy and how financial institutions can start to play their part and think about setting their own robust net-zero commitments.
2. The second session was delivered by Marie Gauthier (Assistant Vice President of Asia Sustainable Finance, WWF) under the asset management workshop delivering “Resilient and sustainable portfolios” on 23rd June 2021, from 2.30pm-3.00pm, with a total of 225 attendees. Marie delivered the introduction on sustainable investing, insight from WWF’s resilient and sustainable portfolios (RESPOND) assessment of asset managers, and high level recommendations for asset managers to improve portfolio resilience and alignment with a low carbon and sustainable future.
3. The third session was delivered by representatives from 2DII, Nicola Stefan Koch (Deputy Head of Retail Investment) & Constanze Bayer (Senior Analyst) under the asset management workshop on 23rd June 2021, from 4.45pm-5.15pm, with a total of 225 attendees. 2DII presented findings from their retail investment programme, what retail investors want from their non-financial goals, understanding what sustainable investment products are currently offered on the market and how “sustainable” financial products are marketed.

The JC3 event was documented and disseminated through video recordings and a rapporteur report. The recording of the sessions are published in the co-organizer youtube channel. The first session can be found here (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=szPmeTujGAk&t=11263s), and the second and third sessions can be found here (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=szPmeTujGAk&t=11263s).  The rapporteur report will be published online by the JC3 subcommitte in due course.

This output is achieved earlier than expected as the conference was conducted earlier than initially planned. WWF have completed all the works (including coordination and invitation of speakers, preparation of presentation materials, participants invitation, etc) prior to the event and prepared the workshop summary of the above sessions (with key takeaways and action points) right after. Therefore, the summary of the workshop can be reported during the first cycle of reporting in 2021 Q2.
Result_Title: Industry-wide workshop and presentation on climate related financial risk and opportunities cutting across the financial sector i.e. banking, investment and insurance.
Description: One industry-level workshop will be implemented for financial institutions, central bank and selected government agencies/ministries. This workshop will help increase the awareness of climate-related financial risk and opportunities. This workshop will lay the groundwork for the more advanced subsequent workshop proposed in the project and ongoing engagement with individual institutions. The workshop is planned to be part of the wider JC3 flagship event (see https://www.bnm.gov.my/-/joint-statement-bnm-sc-greening-the-financial-sector) which is planned to be held in June 2021. WWF is part of the JC3 subcommittee that is championing the JC3 flagship event (Note: WWF is not the event organizer or chair of the JC3 flagship event). Participants are expected to come from all members of the JC3 (banks, asset managers, insurance companies, institutional investors, etc) and key stakeholders (e.g. relevant government agencies). The workshop by WWF and 2DII is expected to be 60-90 minutes and conducted in the form of panel discussion and presentation. However, if the workshop cannot be held as part of the JC3 flagship event, a standalone industry workshop will organized separately. The organizer of JC3 flagship event is targeting an audience of at least 200 participants. The recording of the sessions will be available in YouTube channel of the co-organizer (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rGjVhAod1ZU) and event information is available in the JC3 website hosted by the Malaysia Sustainable Finance Initiative under the Securities Commission Malaysia (https://jc3conference.msfi.com.my/). Summary report from this workshop will also be made available online.

Description: Policy briefing document is developed, based on other project outputs, which aims to inform the development of an EV policy by the City. The eventual EV Policy will state what the City allows and doesn't allow in terms of EV charging.

Project: Building the Green Hydrogen Economy (GHE) Just Energy Transition: Co-creating a Just Labour Transition through the TVET College System in South Africa
Result_Title: Anticipatory Governance training: 1-day workshop with key stakeholders and project beneficiaries to actively explore options with a particular aim of spurring on green hydrogen economy innovations connected to uncertain futures in the hopes of shaping the
Description: About 10 people from the primary and secondary beneficiaries along with union, and labour representatives of the project acquired Anticipatory Governance training for disruptive technologies that seeks to provide a proactive approach to enable government stakeholders to better anticipate and harness new technologies that support the development of a GHE. It also provides a strong innovative base for partnership creation across government, industry and training institutions to facilitate a JET and JLT within a green economy paradigm.

Project: Building the Green Hydrogen Economy (GHE) Just Energy Transition: Co-creating a Just Labour Transition through the TVET College System in South Africa
Result_Title: Multi-Stakeholder Workshop to share research findings through presentations and sharing of policy briefings amongst various stakeholder groups beyond the immediate beneficiaries and secondary beneficiaries
Description: Dissemination all research findings in close collaboration with Department of Science and Innovation

Project: Alternative Financing Models for Embedded Generation of Renewable Energy in South African Municipalities
Result_Title: Municipal and National Embedded Generation policy recommendations
Description: A policy gap analysis will be conducted for each of the municipalities to identify opportunities to improve and add to existing policy to support the implementation of embedded generation projects. This will be based on both desktop analysis and interviews with key stakeholders. Furthermore, through this activity and the process of implementing the project, there will also be an opportunity to develop recommendations for national policy on embedded generation projects.

Project: Alternative Financing Models for Embedded Generation of Renewable Energy in South African Municipalities
Result_Title: Financial Tool to estimate financial feasibility for embedded generation projects in South Africa
Indicator: Output 2.3. 'Project application/ tools developed to access funds'
Description: The financial model will be a tool that is applied in these project municipalities, but one that can also be used by other municipalities who are looking to develop financial feasibility studies for embedded generation projects more quickly.

Project: Alternative Financing Models for Embedded Generation of Renewable Energy in South African Municipalities
Result_Title: Training resources for municipalities
Description: The training resources will be developed for each training session noted above. These training resources will be a set of PowerPoint slides, relevant videos and exercises for a highly interactive training session. All training resources will be digital as it is expected that all training sessions will take place through a virtual platform.

Project: Alternative Financing Models for Embedded Generation of Renewable Energy in South African Municipalities
Result_Title: Embedded generation of renewable energy manual
Description: Building on the training resources developed, a manual will be developed to be used to support municipalities to identify and develop renewable energy embedded generation projects that can attract the necessary finance. This will be publicly available

Project: Alternative Financing Models for Embedded Generation of Renewable Energy in South African Municipalities
Result_Title: Lessons learnt communications product capturing project achievements and insights
Description: To share the lessons and tools emanating from the project to allow for wider scale replication and use by municipalities and others who were not directly part of the project. This output is required to ensure that other potential beneficiaries are aware of what the project has delivered so they may use the outputs to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in the energy sector and to assist the primary beneficiaries to connect with a broader network of governments and institutions committed to renewable energy.

Project: Alternative Financing Models for Embedded Generation of Renewable Energy in South African Municipalities
Result_Title: Project dissemination in global ICLEI Community, 100% Renewable Energy Network, and through social media campaign and webinar
Description: To disseminate the communication products in relevant networks within ICLEI and those held by partner organisations through sharing project articles and resources on relevant websites and in newsletters, engaging in webinars, and through a social media campaign. This will be further specified in the communications plan developed for the project.

Project: Distilling the JET in South Africa: Harmonizing conflict and seeking opportunities
Result_Title: Just transitions capacity building workshop with local stakeholders in Mpumalanga
Description: One training workshop for local stakeholders  - the training will target stakeholders located in Mpumalanga but the exact topic and audience of the training will be determined in the first quarter through the co-development of the project plan

Project: Distilling the JET in South Africa: Harmonizing conflict and seeking opportunities
Result_Title: Project inception engagements in order to on-board stakeholders and co-develop the detailed project plan for co-ownership.
Description: The project inception aims to create awareness as well as buy-in from among key stakeholders. A sub-set will also be invited to seat on the project's Sustainability Task Team. Individual meetings will be held with each stakeholders to understand their priorities and their concerns. This will then be included in the project plan. The final result will be a co-developed and signed-off detailed project design and implementation plan.

Project: Expanding the South African Green Finance Taxonomy and embedding its use
Result_Title: Sustainable Finance Taxonomy Report
Description:
A technical document containing the following:
- An enhanced Phase-1 catalogue and standards of nationally-relevant green activities/innovation needs with more granular criteria, guidance and metrics for complex activities
- An advanced transition finance taxonomy (as sub-component of the green finance taxonomy), with explicit guidance, catalogue and criteria; informed by technology and sector decarbonisation pathways, sustainability-linked instruments; consensus on minimum roadmap requirements; green default monitoring processes
- A Social Finance Taxonomy, with a distinct catalogue and standards for social and socio-economic development activities aligned to and to transition to a green economy with recognition/ requirements, criteria, thresholds and just transition models;
- A non-compatible finance taxonomy: taxonomic exclusion principles; catalogue and criteria of activities, technologies and products that do significant environmental harm; process for reallocation from ‘transition’ to ‘non-compatible’ taxonomies

Project: Expanding the South African Green Finance Taxonomy and embedding its use
Result_Title: Roadmaps
Description: Roadmap for Johannesburg Stock Exchange, South African Reserve Bank, financial sector, Department of Planning ,Monitoring and Evaluation  & Department of Environment, Forest and Fisheries and financial sector to translate the taxonomy into their pre-existing mechanisms, creating demand for the taxonomy and practice alignment.

Project: Expanding the South African Green Finance Taxonomy and embedding its use
Result_Title: User practice guidance, tools and templates associated with the Sustainable Finance Taxonomy
Description: User practice guidance, tools and templates dictated by the Taxonomy Working Group, specific to each component of the enhanced Green Finance Taxonomy and it's collective application

Project: Expanding the South African Green Finance Taxonomy and embedding its use
Result_Title: Open access tools and templates informed by private sector FI pilot projects
Description: Generic tools and templates from private sector FI (financial institution) ;DFI ( Depository Financial Institution); Department of Environment, Forest and Fisheries , Department of Planning, Monitoring and Evaluation; municipality

Project: Business case development for Sector Job Resilience Planning in support of Just Transition in South Africa (Mpumalanga)
Result_Title: Biomass business plan development and SMME evaluation
Indicator: Output 2.3. 'Project application/ tools developed to access funds'
Description: Develop a business case for generating value-added products from invasive alien plant biomass to improve energy security and move towards net zero-carbon emissions in industrial processing and manufacturing. Guided by Biomass Feasibility Report. Identify accessible and utilizable biomass for commercially viable, locally based projects to assist local industries.

Project: A contribution towards a Just Transition Finance Roadmap(JTFR) South Africa
Result_Title: Thought piece on Financial Instruments which can fill market gaps in Just Transition project funding in South Africa
Description:
A thought piece on financial instruments which can fill market gaps in Just Transition project funding in South Africa. This output will inform the roadmap and provided to financial sector stakeholders who are seeking to be innovative in mobilising finance to Just Transition projects. The thought / research piece will contribute to the knowledge base and conversation to enable policy decisions to be taken down the road, will be informed by the TIPS case study funded under GIZ, and would be for information purposes to expand knowledge of the financing required by the Just Transition.

This output is needed because the lack of fiscal space in South Africa and the systemic barriers to early project funding in the South African financial system require novel and new instruments to mobilize funding for Just Transition activities (and new green activities based on innovative technology). We assume the research will seed additional thinking on financial product innovation for the Just Transition in South Africa.

Project: A contribution towards a Just Transition Finance Roadmap(JTFR) South Africa
Result_Title: Meetings with Eskom to make recommendations towards strategies to diversify the Mpumalanga economy as they decommission
Description: The recommendations will support Eskom to meet its internal commitments to support diversified economic activity in Mpumalanga in order to deliver a just energy transition

Project: A contribution towards a Just Transition Finance Roadmap(JTFR) South Africa
Result_Title: Meetings with National Treasury to make recommendations towards financial services regulations
Description: The recommendations will allow the Treasury to better understand the challenges necessary to create an enabling regulatory environment and direct their future actions

Project: A contribution towards a Just Transition Finance Roadmap(JTFR) South Africa
Result_Title: Contribution to a Just Transition Finance Roadmap for South Africa
Description:
The report will seek to provide insights and move the conversation forward on financing of the just transition. It will seek to answer these five questions: 1) how does SA attract foreign concessional funding for Just Transition projects, 2) what will constitute a Just Transition project in SA?, 3) How must SA create policy and guidelines to allow for the alignment of domestic Environment, Social and Governance measurements with international benchmarks, 4) how can SA act to impove the pipeline of bankable Just Transition projects and 5) what type of new and innovative mechanisms and instruments are eeded to mobilise funding to Just Transition projects in SA. The document may include a set of recommendations for key stakeholders. 

This output is needed to begin moving the collective financial services sector and associated regulatory bodies and policy makers further down the track of actions and activities that will support the mainstreaming of Just Transition finance over time in South Africa.

Project: A contribution towards a Just Transition Finance Roadmap(JTFR) South Africa
Result_Title: Business plan on the establishment and operation of a Just Transition Observatory
Description:
The Observatory aims to provide continuity of dialogue and Knowledge sharing across the private sector, public sector, local and foreign investors and funders, labour, civil society and project and programme developers involved with any aspect related to mobilising funding for a Just Transition in SA. The observatory will more specifically undertake the following tasks: 1) data collection and tracking, 2) knowledge product generation, 3) tracking of SA and international policy frameworks, 4) networking and partnering to assist in getting projects implemented, 5) skills development facilitation and 6) awareness and outreach. Tasks/activities that contribute to this output being delivered:
- Finalise mission, vision and advisory board
- Secure necessary resources for operations for 2022-2025 (matchmaking)
- Create JT document repository 
It is expected that the Observatory to be established in 2022. 
The JT Observatory will serve as a permanent connection between the stakeholders and their commitments, as well as the Roadmap, allowing for evolving capacity between partners. The Observatory will continue contributing to the JT dialogue beyond the project implementation, and support knowledge sharing and a community of practice around finance for the JT within SA. The collection of data and information by the Observatory on Just Transition Financing will serve as a monitoring mechanism of the Roadmap implementation and the overall commitment of the financial system towards JT in SA.

Project: A contribution towards a Just Transition Finance Roadmap(JTFR) South Africa
Result_Title: Online webinar to share project outputs
Description: A 2 hour online seminar will be held of approximatley 50 people to disseminate and engage on the outputs, share information, seed ideas, create some traction on JT investment in SA, increase awareness of opportunities to mobilise funding in SA, and discuss issues. The seminar will have the 3 papers presented (Financial Instruments, Scalability, Communications and Outreach) with discussion on of the papers. Combined webinar on the 3 thought pieces / policy briefs; one on JT qualification criteria and measurement; one on anchor projects available for funding; one on presentation of JTFR.

Project: A contribution towards a Just Transition Finance Roadmap(JTFR) South Africa
Result_Title: Thought piece on achieving scalability of community just transition projects in South Africa
Description:
This research report on scalability of community just transition projects which require Just Transition finance, and how this finance is to be mobilised. This output will contribute to new finance product development as well as increase pipeline of bankable projects. Scalability will improve the attractiveness of such investments to the financial services sector. 

This output is needed because in all Discovery Phase interactions with financial sector players (local and global), the issue of scalability and replicability was raised as a major constraint on funding mobilisation.

Project: A contribution towards a Just Transition Finance Roadmap(JTFR) South Africa
Result_Title: Comparative Study: Just Transition in India and South Africa
Description: HKS (Harvard kennedy School) to prepare a paper (co-funded with CDC) that outlines and compares the Just Transition  financing situations in both South Africa and India. Both countries are high coal dependent emerging countries who are thinking about a Just Transition, and CDC (co-funder of the project) are active in both regions. The project has been designed together with a similar project being implemented in India. The experience in both countries will allow for a comparison of results and sharing lessons learned. The study will be shared with the target audience directly, as well as published online.

Project: A contribution towards a Just Transition Finance Roadmap(JTFR) South Africa
Result_Title: Input to COP26 Report
Description:
As part of the requirements from the co-funder (CDC) an input will be prepared that can be presented at an event they will arrange in partnership with the Harvard Kennedy School and London School of Economics. It will be either at COP26 or a pre-COP26 event on financing and the Just Tranisition. The paper, which aims to share new insights, will show at a high level how the South African and global financial community are contributing to the Just Energy Transition in Mpumalanga and the opportunities and challenges that are currently being faced.

This output is needed to take advantage of the opportunity to place the South Africa Just Transition agenda and investment opportunities on a global platform.

Project: STRAPSA - Shifting the transport  paradigm  for South Africa
Result_Title: Green Procurement Guidelines and Standards to Promote Electric Vehicle Fleets
Description: Developed Infrastructure green procurement guidelines and standards to promote electric vehicle fleets.  The document will contain recommendations around best practices to support the adoption of green procurement guidelines to promote electric vehicle fleets. The recommendations will be submitted to the Department of Transport: Integrated Transport Planning Division, to support the following key performance indicator within the Green Transport Strategy: Develop guidelines for the procurement of vehicles throughout government to procure efficient vehicles, using clean energy technologies. The recommendations will be targeting: Department of Transport: Integrated Transport Planning Division; National Treasury: Senior Management responsible for Strategic Planning and Senior Staff within the Government Technical Advisory Centre; Department of Trade, Industry and Competition: Senior Management within the Industrial Development Division: Green Industries, Automotive Sector; Department of Environment, Forestry and Fisheries: Senior Management within the Climate Change and Air Quality Branch.

Project: STRAPSA - Shifting the transport  paradigm  for South Africa
Result_Title: Communication products (e.g. presentations, leaflets, press releases) for guidelines and standards for green infrastructure procurement
Description: Press Release, Electronic leaflet and presentation for green infrastructure procurement guidelines and standards, made available for dissemination throughout the beneficiaries' organisations as well as the general public

Project: Climate Transition Pathways
Result_Title: Low Carbon Pathways Report (2.2)
Description: This is an in-depth research report which provides the findings from the climate transition research undertaken. It will have chapters on individual sectors (which can be published seperately) as well as chapters on more general chapters on policy and other actions that need to occur for a low carbon transition to occur in line with Paris Agreement. It aims to influence key decision makers by providing in-depth analysis on transitions pathways and impacts on jobs and other social dimensions. The Low Carbon Pathways report will provide findings from the climate transition research and provide analysis on transition pathways and impact on job and social dimensions in electricity, mining, petro-chemical, and topical sectors. This report will provide recommendations on policy actions to encourage decarbonization in these sectors in line with the Paris Agreement.

Project: Climate Transition Pathways
Result_Title: Low Carbon Pathways Report (2.1)
Description: The Low Carbon Pathways report will provide findings from the climate transition research and provide analysis on transition pathways and impact on job and social dimensions in electricity, mining, petro-chemical, and topical sectors, and will provide recommendations to the government on developing ,financing and implementing low-carbon pathways . The chapters will also be published as standalone documents.

Project: Climate Transition Pathways
Result_Title: Recommendations for transition to low carbon economy
Description: Recommendation for proposed policy made to the DEFF and Department of Energy for South Africa on how to transition to a low carbon economy ahead of COP 26.

Project: Climate Transition Pathways
Result_Title: Low Carbon Pathways Report Launch
Description: A launch event to showcase the report produced incorporating all the research and inputs from stakeholders.

Project: Paving the Way for Setting Ambitious GHG Emissions Reductions in the Private Sector to enhance the National Climate Change Policy
Result_Title: Recommendations to 4 Mexican companies on the science-based target setting models and options
Description: Recommendations to 4 Mexican companies on the science-based target setting models and options (through the CSM pilot), including scenarios and sectorial pathways (if available) that best suit the companies' goals

Project: Accelerating Green Finance Flows Through the Strengthening of the Mexican National Banking and Securities Commission (CNBV)
Result_Title: Green finance dissemination campaign developed to raise CNBV’s awareness and support institutional transformation
Description: This output aims to disseminate  material/products on green finance. A dissemination campaign will be developed and implemented throughout the project’s life cycle to foster awareness and knowledge/understanding of ESG and green finance. Contents will be developed based on the outputs 1,2, 3, 4, and disseminated every two months. The dissemination material will support capacity building efforts and disseminate reports findings. Output activities will be developed in closed collaboration with CNBV’s Communication (internal and external) Directorates  and other relevant Directorates.

Project: Accelerating Green Finance Flows Through the Strengthening of the Mexican National Banking and Securities Commission (CNBV)
Result_Title: Establishment and institutionalisation of a Green Finance Task Force (GFTF) within CNBV
Description: This output aims to establish a network of key actors in green finance in Mexico. A task force group on green finance is needed to support coordination and communication among relevant areas within the CNBV. It will provide clear guidance in case of high employee turnover, ensure all efforts permeate evenly within the Commission and inform subsequent soft and hard regulation of the financial sector. Through the engagement with the Green Finance Task Force, a permanent Working Group will be established towards the end of the project to ensure continuity and follow up on the developing efforts on sustainable finance beyond the project. There are seven directorates initially identified to form part of the taskforce.

Project: Strengthening the use of Earth Observation platforms to support the implementation of climate change mitigation goals in the forest and land use sector in three states in Mexico.
Result_Title: Early Warning Deforestation Alert System
Description: The project will set up early warning deforestation alerts linked to existing land use maps using the EO Lab platform.
Implementor: Ecometrica Ltd. (Ecosistemas Consultoría Integral para Soluciones sustentables)

Project: Supporting the roll-out of smart grid technologies in Colombia Phase 2: Moving forward to implementation
Result_Title: Report identifying the economic benefits of ToU tariff to end-users
Description:
The report will contain findings regarding the economic benefits that the implementation of a ToU tariff will bring to end-users in Colombia and the impact on net demand.
This output is relevant because the economic benefit for end users is a key driver for action. UPME needs such information before providing recommendations on ToU tariff implementation in the country.

Project: Supporting the roll-out of smart grid technologies in Colombia Phase 2: Moving forward to implementation
Result_Title: Database with clusters of representative energy demand profiles
Description:
This will be an Excel database with clusters of representative energy demand profiles identified by residential, industrial and commercial energy consumers to help UPME understand the potential for the deployment of smart technologies by sectors and geographic regions.
This output will allow UPME to improve their level of understanding of demand at the client level and its potential for flexible provision, allowing them improve their forecasts of regional and national demand, as well as use as key inputs to define their National Energy Plans.

Project: Supporting the roll-out of smart grid technologies in Colombia Phase 2: Moving forward to implementation
Result_Title: Diplomados and Short Courses on smart grids and digital transformation (online & in-person)
Description:
Skills will be enhanced through the delivery of a structured training program that will be a minimum of 120 hours and deliver a diploma certificate of Universidad Nacional de Colombia to each attendee. This program will have modules with strategic content focused on decision-makers, and others with technical content focused on the technical staff of the beneficiaries and other supportive stakeholders of the project.  

This training necessary because the need was clearly identified in the Round 1 Project to ensure that the key stakeholders of the Colombian energy sector have the skills to develop, operate and interact with a smart grid in Colombia, which is necessary condition to unlock the accelerated deployment of flexibility from the demand side and its associated carbon emission abatement potential. 

-20 people: Diplomados on Smart Grids
-20 people: Diplomados on Digital Transformation
-30 people: Short course on Smart Grids
-20 people: Short course cybersecurity and interoperability
-20 people: Short course on Smart Grids IT and communications
-12 people: Short course on Smart Grids business models
-12 people: Short course on Smart Grids regulation
